Go to Carbon82's profileCarbon82Member's total reputation
 203,592
	
		6,462 posts
URA Draft Master Plan: More housing planned for CBD, Marina Bay area
 

 
SINGAPORE: More homes will be built in the central business district (CBD) and Marina Bay area, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) said on Wednesday (Mar 27).
 
Under its Draft Master Plan 2019, which includes plans to rejuvenate the central area, URA said it will increase housing in sites such as Downtown, Marina South and Rochor so that more people can live closer to their workplaces and other amenities.
 
The plan for a larger live-in population in the office-dominated CBD and Marina Bay area is part of a move by URA to bring more life to the area after office hours.
 
"We are looking to bring in new housing options in the CBD. We want to make our CBD more vibrant, a 24/7 precinct, and housing is one of the ways where we want to bring in more people that will be living within the CBD areas," said Ms Hwang Yu-Ning, URA’s chief planner.
 

The central area also includes retail and entertainment clusters at Orchard and the Singapore River, as well as arts, cultural and heritage areas such as the Civic District, Bras Basah and Bugis.
 
Further south, the site currently occupied by Keppel Club will also be redeveloped for waterfront housing after the current lease expires in 2021, URA said.
 
The site - which is close to Telok Blangah and Labrador MRT stations - is part of the expansive 2,000-hectare Greater Southern Waterfront project stretching from Pasir Panjang to Marina East.
 
Some of the development in the Greater Southern Waterfront will begin within the next five to 10 years.
 

MORE HOUSING IN MATURE ESTATES
 
Besides the central area, new housing and amenities will be also added to the new Bayshore precinct in the Upper East Coast area, and the mature towns of Dakota Crescent and Farrer Park.
 
A park will be built along the old sea walls, which are characteristic of East Coast Park, as a reminder of its heritage.
 
When completed, the new Bayshore precinct will have two MRT stations, Bayshore and Bedok South MRT stations. It will also be a car-lite precinct, prioritising walking and cycling with a public transit street lined with shops, food outlets and amenities.
 
URA said that going forward, future residential precincts will continue to be sustainable, green, community-centric and car-lite, with easy access to a range of public spaces and amenities. Amenities will also be located in one-stop centres similar to Our Tampines Hub to make it easier for residents to shop, dine and engage in family-bonding activities under one roof.
 

For an existing mature town such as Farrer Park, new housing will open up choices for those seeking to live near the city, URA said. Familiar landmarks such as the Farrer Park Swimming Pool and former Boxing Gym will be retained, while a sports field and park that will be integrated with future housing will allow residents to bond over sports and recreational activities, said URA.
 
Dakota Crescent can expect to see more public housing, which will be planned around the six preserved Singapore Improvement Trust blocks nearby, while the iconic Dove Playground will be retained for its heritage value.
 
BRINGING JOBS CLOSER TO HOMES WITH THREE "GATEWAYS"
 
Aside from housing, three major economic gateways in the west, north and east are being planned with each anchored in a few key growth sectors. They will serve as major employment hubs.
 
The eastern gateway is centred in the Changi region to tap on the expansion of Changi Airport and its connectivity. The region comprises Changi Aviation Park and the future Changi East Industrial Zone, and will cater to aviation-related businesses.
 

Also part of the region is Changi City, which is slated to become an innovative lifestyle business cluster including Changi Business Park, Singapore University of Technology and Design, as well as the future Changi East Urban District located at the doorstep at Terminal 5.
 
The northern gateway stretches from Woodlands to Punggol and will focus on the agri-tech and food sectors, digital tech and cybersecurity sectors.
 

In Sungei Kadut, the new Agri-Food Innovation Park will be built as a pilot cluster to catalyse innovation in the agri-tech industry. The park, which is located near to farms in Lim Chu Kang and businesses in the Senoko Food Zone, forms part of a larger Northern Agri-Tech and Food Corridor.
 



In Woodlands, a new regional centre is on track to become the largest economic hub in the north over the next 15 years with spaces for business, industry, research and development, and learning and innovation.
 
New community links such as the WoodsVista Gallery and North Coast Vista will link up precincts within Woodlands and bring in more public spaces, and pedestrian and cycling infrastructure to the area.
 
To the east, the Punggol Digital District – Singapore’s first enterprise district – will see the co-location of a business park with the Singapore Institute of Technology university to help foster closer collaboration between industry and academia.
 

Tapping on Tuas Terminal’s maritime connectivity, the western gateway will be moored alongside the Jurong Lake District and Jurong Innovation District.
 
As part of the Government’s decentralisation strategy, Jurong Lake District will be the biggest business district outside the CBD while Jurong Innovation District will become a next-generation industrial district covering Nanyang Technological University, CleanTech Park, Bulim, Bahar and Tengah.
 
URA’s Master Plan is reviewed every five years and charts out the Government’s plans for land use over the next 10 to 15 years.
 
“In this master plan, we hope to have inclusive, sustainable and green neighbourhoods that will make our city more resilient in the longer term. We are also working on plans to help rejuvenate existing familiar places to make sure we bring in new vibrancy and energy to these areas,” said Ms Hwang.
 
 





URA Draft Master Plan: Going underground to free up space on the surface
 



 
SINGAPORE: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is using special 3D technology to study the underground as a strategic resource, it said on Wednesday (Mar 27) at the launch of its Draft Master Plan 2019. 
 
The Master Plan is a blueprint that guides Singapore's development over the next 10 to 15 years and is reviewed every five years. 
 
URA said it has rolled out 3D underground maps for Marina Bay, Jurong Innovation District and Punggol Digital District, and plans to expand the pilot to include more areas.
 

Called the Special and Detailed Control Plan (SCDP), the map shows planned underground uses for each district in 3D, which can help protect planning intention. 
 
"The underground plan is part of our strategy to create spaces for the future and create capacity for growth. Providing the plans for the underground provides transparency to the developers. This is more for the shallow underground, but we are also looking at plans for the deeper caverns. That's for deeper utilities and structures that will go underground," said Ms Hwang Yu-Ning, chief planner at URA.
 
The authority is studying the possibility of freeing up surface land for people-centric uses and relocating utilities, transport, storage and industrial facilities to the underground. 
 

An example of this, she said, is the new substation in the Labrador, Pasir Panjang area, which has the capacity to power more than two public housing towns. Building the substation underground frees up three hectares of land. 
 
"The 230kV substation will go underground and that frees up ... about 3ha of land on top for a future office development. It will also free up the space for other people to enjoy rather than look at utilities above ground," Ms Hwang added. 
 
Depending on the depth, the purposes for underground spaces may vary. In shallower depths, underground connections and MRT stations can be built. Deeper spots such as the Jurong Rock Caverns can store liquid hydrocarbons like gas oil and crude oil.
 
There are two existing caverns, and JTC and PUB are conducting cavern studies. Cavern areas currently under study are Kent Ridge Hill, Tanjong Kling, Jurong West and Gali Batu.

Condo rentals in these areas will get depressed over the long term.

But new HDB developments would be a good buy.

Yup I know - cdl won the new bid instead of guoccoland 
 
What I’m saying is the previous developer (guoccoland) doesn’t even want to make a higher bid price for the new sims drive site...
Essentially what they are doing is to set a `floor’ price to protect their Sims Oasis.  If they won, they do not necessary have to sell at a lower price.  In fact, they could just sell at the same price and earn a bigger margin (ignoring higher construction costs here).  And if the market is really going south, they could average down their land cost in this area.  Win-win.   
But in the end, HL came to `support’ the land price here by bidding higher than Sims Oasis land cost.  Having said that, CDL did launch Whistler Grand at cut-throat price unexpected by the market in the West Coast area....so they can do the same here too...

I think interest rate is a bigger factor than income levels. Low interest rates allow people to buy more expensive houses than what their income can afford. Just look around this forum lah.  
If u think closely, u want to buy when interest rates are High not Low. I was betting interest rates will not go up further. The threat of rising interest did convince some sellers to drop prices to exit the market. I got my unit close to the 2017 bottom price. 
 
Of course not everyone takes a loan, but who sets the price?? The buyer who is willing to pay the highest, investors speculators, and the sellers who is willing to take the lowest, people who need to exit. Just look at why our property market moves when interest rates fell. Was it because our income went up?

One important consideration is while everyone needs to buy a house, does everyone need to buy a private (versus HDB)?
 
So we talk about relative inelastic nature of this demand and imperfect substitutes of housing (for each other).

Go to therock's profiletherockMember's total reputation

		7,828 posts
The private vs HDB is both a practical and emotion debate..
 
Private estates, well, are supposed to afford the buyer some privacy, and whether it's PC or not, also afford you some separation from the masses, for those who feel they don't want to mingle with average Joe.
There are also facilities, and these are supposed to be less crowded.
 
Emotional? Well, the same reason Mercs, BMWs and even Lexus sells. The message is I've arrived. 
 
As one Toyota hater loves to put it: the HDB is much more value for money, cost less and gives you the same surface area and number of rooms/doors and toilets.
So why do people buy these private units at twice or more?
 
I think not everyone wants or is allowed to buy HDB... 
 
Having lived and looked into some units, the insides are nice, especially the modern ones, but the difference can be vast outside your own unit. Who you live next to, where the unit is sited, what is around it etc, is much less under your control.
 
Nevertheless, each time I drive past this Tiong Bahru block, I regret not buying it :(
 
Fabulous location, and great condition but at that time, I thought 500k was expensive... oh well... 

I am very puzzled where is there so much "noise" no rise on cost of living and even NTUC has to come and freeze 100 product prices.
 
But you still loads of people queueing to buy properties. Where do these people get all the money to buy? Can't be all Rolex saleman right?

Some folks earn enough, others feel they earn enough and can borrow the rest, others feel their parents earn enough to help them, and yet others have earned enough from past sales profits to get one.
 
Cost of living? Well each time we ask for a pay rise, the cost of living goes up somehow too...

https://www.sgsme.sg/news/13m-business-loss-proves-priceless-property-couple
$1.3m business loss proves priceless for property couple
 

Q What is in your portfolio?
A My initial allocation of investment funds was 20 per cent in business and 80 per cent in property.
 
The portfolio has since evolved to business (45 per cent), properties (45 per cent) and insurance (10 per cent).
 
In terms of real estate, we own six industrial properties under our personal names, another five industrial properties via partnership with our friends, and one residential property.
 
The leasehold of our industrial properties is between 38 and 52 years.
 
Q What are your immediate investment plans?
A I will continue investing in industrial properties in Singapore to gain high returns of rental income.
 
At the same time, my company has started exploring overseas properties to provide passive income after deducting expenses. 
 
My property investment strategy will always follow these two rules, of leverage from bank loans and positive passive monthly income after expenses.

this is the part that not many people truly "understand" the meaning of using cpf to invest in hdb/propertyExactly. Makes no sense. 
My money in the bank, bank pays me interest.
 
I take out money from the bank, no interest is paid to me.
 
I put money back into the bank, I don't need to pay back any accrued interest.
 
So why CPF so special?
Go to Wt_know's profileWt_knowMember's total reputation
 52,458
	
		25,016 posts

Exactly. Makes no sense.
 
My money in the bank, bank pays me interest.
 
I take out money from the bank, no interest is paid to me.
 
I put money back into the bank, I don't need to pay back any accrued interest.
 
So why CPF so special?
because cpf is a “compulsory” saving compulsory saving comes with compulsory interest
if you use the money for a period of time
you have to pay back the interest for “that” period of time
cpf is your money but you are governed by a set of rules
you are the true owner of the money when you withdraw at 55 and put them in your pocket
then you can blow all the money at rws/mbs or ah tiong bu! 
 
until the money is in your pocket/bank
ya’ll just listen and suck thumb ... ok

What is non refundable ABSD? 
 
I googled but can't find.
In most situations, ABSD are non-refundable unless you meet the conditions for ABSD remission in the link below: 
https://www.iras.gov.sg/irashome/uploadedFiles/IRASHome/Other_Taxes/Stamp_Duty_for_Property/Claiming_Refunds_Remissions_Reliefs/Remissions/ABSD%20Rates%20or%20Remission%20for%20Joint%20Purchase%20by%20a%20Married%20Couple_2018-07-06.pdf

https://www.99.co/blog/singapore/5-common-bits-of-fake-news-about-singapore-property/
5 Common Bits of “Fake News” About Singapore Property
 

1. HDB flat prices will always go up
 
2. Freehold condos are always better, because buyers are scared of expiring leases
 
3. You can always refinance into a cheaper loan package later
 
4. Once you turn 55, you cannot pay for your flat with your CPF
 
5. If you sell your flat for a loss, you have to “compensate” CPF when returning your sales proceeds
 
A second part to this bit of fake news: money returned this way can’t be used to buy another house, if you’re 55 or older

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://sbr.com.sg/residential-property/news/condo-resale-prices-35-in-march
Condo resale prices up 3.5% in March
 
 

Prices of OCR condos rose 5.1%.
 
Private condo resale prices rose 3.5% YoY in March, according to data from SRX Property. Rates outside the central region (OCR) led the increase by 5.1% YoY.
 
Condo resale prices in the rest of the central region (RCR) and the core central region (CCR) also rose 3.1% and 0.6% YoY, respectively in March. On a MoM basis, OCR saw condo resale prices rose 1.3% whilst prices in the CCR decreased 2.1% and RCR rates remained unchanged.
 
The volume of resale condos edged up 59.3% MoM to 830 in March from 521 units resold in February. On a YoY basis, however, the units transacted were 41.4% lower compared to the 1,417 units resold in March 2018.
 
"The trend may indicate that marketing activities arising from new project launches may spur buying interest in the secondary market within the vicinity. We may expect buying interest for resale homes to pick-up further in selected locations as more projects will be launched in the coming months."

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/pebble-bay-resale-unit-reaps-29-mil-profit
 

A unit sold on March 27 at Pebble Bay, on Tanjong Rhu Road in District 15, made the top gain of $2.85 million in the week of March 26 to April 2. The 2,809 sq ft, four-bedroom unit on the 15th floor was purchased for $2.26 million ($804 psf) in March 1995, and sold for $5.1 million ($1,815 psf). The seller reaped a 127% profit.
 
The second top gain made over the week – a 162% profit of $2.04 million – was at Allsworth Park, along Holland Road in District 10. The 1,959 sq ft, three-bedroom unit on the eighth floor was bought for $1.26 million ($643 psf) in April 2001, and sold for $3.3 million ($1,684 psf) on March 28. 
 
A unit sold at Casa Esperanza, on Bukit Timah Road in District 21, was the third most profitable transaction over the week, raking in a 108% profit of $1.66 million for the seller. The 2,164 sq ft, three-bedroom unit on the 10th floor was purchased in June 1999 for $1.54 million ($710 psf), and sold for $3.2 million ($1,479 psf) on March 27. 
 
 
Meanwhile the greatest loss incurred over the week was from the resale of a 2,282 sq ft unit at Orchard Scotts, off Scotts Road in District 9. Having sold the property for $3.3 million ($1,446 psf) on March 28, the seller sustained a 27% loss of $1.25 million. The unit was purchased in December 2010 for $4.55 million ($1,994 psf).

https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/new-private-home-sales-launches-up-in-march
New private home sales, launches up in March
 

Developers in Singapore sold 1,054 private homes in March, up from the 455 units they moved in February, and 47 per cent higher than the 716 units they sold in the corresponding month a year ago.
 
Including ECs, which are a public-private housing hybrid, developers found buyers for 1,062 units last month, higher than the 457 units they moved in February and the 788 units they sold in March a year ago.

OK, while we are at HKG. I doubt we will see a repeat in SG yet, but in a years' time, the probability will rise substantially as the pent-up demand continues to build.
 

Hong Kong & ChinaHong Kong’s homebuyers return in droves as banks kept mortgage rates unchanged amid a dovish monetary policyAcross the city, 607 flats were offered for open sale by four developers in Lohas Park, To Kwan Wan, Yau Tong and West Kowloon
Thousands of people queued for the 294 properties on offer at New World’s Artisan Garden


 

 
Lam Ka-sing  

Published: 5:30pm, 23 Mar, 2019
 





 


 





Up to 3,700 prospective buyers queuing up for the 294 flats of New World Development's Artisan Garden project on Saturday, 23 March 2019. Photo: SCMP / Dickson Lee



Hong Kong’s property buyers are back in droves, as commercial banks kept the city’s mortgage rates unchanged amid a dovish policy stance by the local monetary authority.
Across the city, four property projects with 607 flats in total were offered for sale in Lohas Park, To Kwa Wan, Yau Tong and West Kowloon in the biggest weekend launch in a year. As of 8pm, 496 of the total offering, or nearly 82 per cent, had been sold, according to sales agents.
“The purchasing power accumulated from months of pent-up demand had been released,” said Midland Realty’s residential division chief executive Sammy Po, who noted that five buyers had each bought two flats for a weekend shopping bill of between HK$12 million and HK$13 million.
 

 

Hong Kong’s property bull market had been struggling to regain its footing since prices stumbled last August following the city government’s plan to use a vacancy tax to bolster supply. The weekend’s brisk sales – combined with a slight increase in pricing – stoked concerns that housing affordability may return as a problem, after five months of cooling off.
Hong Kong home prices are back on the rise, stoked by dovish Fed
Last week, the city’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor chimed in to express her concern about housing prices, which were showing signs of revival. Hong Kong is still one of the world’s most expensive urban centres, putting housing beyond the reach of many first-time buyers and school leavers.
Still, eight months after prices began to dip, many buyers were already jumping back into the market, especially for newer projects like New World Development’s Artisan Garden project in To Kwa Wan, which drew 3,700 bids for 294 available units.

 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/homebuyers-hold-purchases-amid-hopes-lower-prices
Homebuyers hold off purchases amid hopes of lower prices
 

More than nine months after the latest property cooling measures were implemented in July last year, homebuyers are still holding off on purchases. “Most people are not buying because they just don’t want to pay the additional buyer’s stamp duty (ABSD),”
 
Avalanche of potential upgraders
 
While the higher ABSD and tightened LTV ratio continue to impact homebuyers’ affordability, property hunters are not putting off buying a new property. “We believe there is pent-up demand building up, and we suspect that it is likely to come back,” 
 
Most of this demand will come from HDB upgraders, who have contributed to more than a third of new private home buyers for the past 24 years. “From 2019 to 2022, there will be a record number of HDB flats reaching their minimum occupation period (MOP). This means their owners will be eligible to sell the flats in the open market,”
 
In a sign that HDB owners are selling their properties, the HDB resale volume has been increasing since 2014, from 17,318 transactions to last year’s 23,099 transactions. This segment of buyers is picking up private properties due to the divergence between the price index of private properties and that of HDB properties since 2Q2017.

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/oxley-targets-younger-homebuyers
 

Since April 2018, Oxley has launched nine development projects, and the response from buyers has been “overwhelming”, according to the group’s February announcement on the Singapore Exchange.
 
With more than 1,700 units sold in residential projects in Singapore, Oxley has amassed total sales of $1.926 billion, it said in a February corporate presentation. The numbers have gone up since, especially after the group launched its latest mixed-use development, 1953, last month.
 
Three of the group’s projects – The Verandah Residences, Sixteen35 Residences, and Sea Pavilion Residences – are fully sold.
 
 
Mayfair Collection is made up of the 215-unit Mayfair Gardens and the 171-unit Mayfair Modern. More than 130 units at Mayfair Gardens have been sold since its launch last October, with average price at $1,934 psf.
Located on South Buona Vista Road, off Pasir Panjang Road, Kent Ridge Hill sold 110 units out of 250 released on Nov 10, the first day of launch.
 
Oxley also launched two mega projects, the 1,052- unit Affinity at Serangoon and the 1,427-uinit Riverfront Residences in the northeastern part of Singapore last year.
Riverfront Residences, the project is currently 64% sold. Affinity at Serangoon, as at April 15, 491 units (about 47% of the total project) have been sold at an average price of $1,507 psf.
 
1953, a mixed-use development located on the corner of Balestier Road and Tessensohn Road, was launched over the weekend of March 9 and 10. Oxley said that a total of 22 residential and three commercial units were sold that first weekend. The residential units fetched an average price of $1,875 psf, while the commercial units were sold at an average of $3,200 psf.
The boutique development contains 72 units, of which 58 are apartments and 14 are strata commercial units.

https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/sun-rosier-condo-fetches-271m-in-singapores-latest-en-bloc-sale
Sun Rosier condo fetches $271m in latest en-bloc sale, 15% higher than asking price
 

the condominium off Bartley Road fetched a top bid of S$271 million in Singapore's latest collective sale, about 15 per cent more than the asking price of S$235 million.
 
The offer works out to S$1,325 per sq ft per plot ratio, compared with the S$1,149 psf ppr asking price for the 146,046 sq ft site.
 
At this price, each unit owner stands to receive an estimated S$2.86 million to S$4.77 million, averaging S$1,885 psf. This is 108 per cent over the last transacted price for a unit sold early this year, or twice of what each unit could fetch if sold individually and not collectively.

https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/how-sun-park-sold-en-bloc-for-8109m-on-third-try 

It is a case of third time lucky for owners at How Sun Park after they finally sold their estate en-bloc - reaping a knockout price in the process.
 
A unit of the SingHaiyi Group is paying $81.09 million for the freehold estate comprising a three-storey development of 20 townhouses. Owners will get about $4.05 million per unit - slightly more than twice what they would have received had their units been sold individually.
 
The price works out to $1,092 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), inclusive of an estimated development charge of $2.92 million.
 
"The owners' reserve price was reasonable, at $70 million, which is why the site has drawn interest."

alot of buyers will want new, fresh lease and everything new and don't mind paying more. Lease is very sensitive to them.Lease is not a factor for FH/999. But I can see the rationale for preferring new. Now enbloc and buy new, earn money and avoid hefty repairs for old buildings. 
That said, even for FH, for those which have already enbloc once for example in early 2010s and achieved TOP in mid 2010s. 20-30 years later, when the condo ages, what are the chances of enbloc again? 
 
Given the high prices now, to enbloc again in future will be even more expensive. They'd have no choice but to fork out high sums of money for big repairs. If the sinking fund is not enough, good luck to the owners.

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
One will need to study how the plot ratio and GFA is adjusted over time, in order to answer your question.
 
There is no choice but to adjust the GFA ratio 30 years later. A better set of questions will be:
 
1. What are the incomes people should be earning 30 years later?
 
2. What are the implications if Singapore comprises only old and dilapidated private properties (i.e. not possible to enbloc)?
 
3. Why are private property prices always high? They were high 10, 20 even 30 years ago based on the respective incomes of those in that era, relative to other options such as HDB. Would there be a time when they are considered cheap relative to HDB?
 
 
Lease is not a factor for FH/999. But I can see the rationale for preferring new. Now enbloc and buy new, earn money and avoid hefty repairs for old buildings.That said, even for FH, for those which have already enbloc once for example in early 2010s and achieved TOP in mid 2010s. 20-30 years later, when the condo ages, what are the chances of enbloc again?Given the high prices now, to enbloc again in future will be even more expensive. They'd have no choice but to fork out high sums of money for big repairs. If the sinking fund is not enough, good luck to the owners.

https://www.asiaone.com/singapore/property-are-executive-condominiums-worth-buying
Property: Are executive condominiums worth buying?
 

The next EC launch - in Sumang Walk - is expected to be later this year. Due to the low supply, EC prices have steadily increased. A unit at Northwave was sold in January for S$864 per square foot (psf), a 15 per cent increase from the project's median price of S$751 psf when it was launched back in July 2016.
 
the Sumang Walk site sold at a record S$583 psf ppr to City Developments Limited (CDL) and TID Residential. Reports have estimated the breakeven price for the development to be almost S$1,000 psf.

Chinatown Point Mall Sold for $520 million
 

Nine years ago, Perennial Real Estate Holdings led a group of investors to acquire Chinatown Point Mall for $250 million; Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) was one of the group.  
Today, Chinatown Point Mall is being sold to Pan Asia Realty Advisors (PAR) for $520 million – a 108 per cent gain over the original price

UNDER THE HAMMER: Unit at Modena going for $1.46 mil
 

A 1,539 sq ft, three-bedroom unit at Modena, along Simei Street 4 in District 18, will be put up for its second auction on April 30.
 
The tenth-floor unit will be sold with vacant possession, on an “as is where is” basis. The previous owner purchased it for $708,000 ($460 psf) in July 2003.

https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/private-home-rents-recover-with-1-rise-in-q1-vacancy-rate-dips-to-63-ura
Private home rents recover with 1% rise in Q1; vacancy rate dips to 6.3% : URA
 

Rents of landed properties increased by 0.2 per cent in the January to March quarter, compared with the 2.1 per cent drop in the previous quarter. Rents of non-landed properties increased by 1.1 per cent, compared with the 0.8 per cent decline in the prior quarter.
 
The vacancy rate of completed private residential units (excluding ECs) dipped to 6.3 per cent at the end of the first quarter of this year, down a notch from 6.4 per cent in the previous quarter.
 
Another bright spot, was a decrease in vacancy rates of completed private residential homes (excluding ECs) for six consecutive quarters, to a five-year low of 6.3 per cent.

https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/lure-seven-year-guarantee-citadines-berawa-beach-bali
The lure of the seven-year guarantee: 
 

The developer is offering investors is a guaranteed rental return (GRR) of 5% for seven years, with no lock-in period, and also absorbing the withholding tax of 10% on the GRR of 5% for the entire seven-year period.
 
Full payment, 5% return
 
The developer is offering three payment schemes: full payment with a 15% discount; progressive payment with a 10% discount; and a seven-year payment scheme with a 5% discount.
 
The studio suites start from $230,000, the equivalent of just the downpayment for a condo in Singapore or some properties in the more mature markets.
Definitely, as with any investment foreign or domestic, the usual rule applies ... high risk high return.For locals, nothing beats having the knowledge and assurance of 'home ground advantage'

https://www.propertyguru.com.sg/property-management-news/2019/4/179738/home-prices-to-hold-steady-despite-property-cooling-measures
Home Prices To Hold Steady Despite Property Cooling Measures
 

This comes as most developers launching new projects this year had paid high prices for land during the en bloc fever that commenced at around May 2017.
 
Developers will also be more willing to maintain prices and accept a lower sell-down rate rather than resort to discounting, which may devalue the overall project as well as disappoint earlier buyers who forked out higher prices.
 
Some developers may be incentivised to resort to heavy discounting to sell all remaining units within five years of being awarded the land in order to recoup the remissible portions of developer’s Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD), which is sizable at 25 per cent (an increase from the previous 15 per cent). However, Teo shares that the number of developments that will reach the five-year deadline from now till 2020 is relatively low, with less than 200 units in total.
 
Instead of steep offering discounts, he expects developers to position their projects more competitively moving forward, especially in view of the large supply of properties in the pipeline.
 
Aside from early bird discounts, developers may offer higher sales commissions to agents as well as deferred payment arrangements for completed project in order to boost sales.

https://www.propertyguru.com.sg/property-management-news/2019/4/179755/private-home-acquisition-by-singaporeans-soar-in-q1-2019
Private Home Acquisition By Singaporeans Soar In Q1 2019
 

Singaporeans’ share of local home purchases rose the highest in a decade versus foreigners, with 79 percent of private apartments snapped up by locals during the first quarter of 2019.
 
In fact, the proportion of locals acquiring luxury homes soared 69 percent from 36 percent over the same period last year.
 
“The rising number of affluent locals purchasing luxury homes indicates their confidence that Singapore remains a safe haven for capital preservation and appreciation,” 
 
The highest number of sales for super-luxury new condos, or those priced over $3,500 per sq ft (psf) was also registered in Q1 2019 after more than a decade. A penthouse within a development close to the Orchard Road shopping district was sold for $28 million or $4,927 psf.

A decent sized 3 bedroom brand new condo

A 1600 sq ft LH landed in a decent area with good amenities and transport nodes
A <1000 sq ft FH landed at Macpherson which needs work or maybe a larger FH older place in Sembawang or some place more than 40 min from CDB.... and don't forget to budget for renovations..
 
Take your pick...

Go to Icedbs's profileIcedbsMember's total reputation
 16,579
	
		6,254 posts
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IHvZtaEgnbI&feature=youtu.be&fbclid=IwAR0gBS2MguGcORmcJjKweWzAP--XOvc4_e_QzDYOuC63QEPnGY4RhGhWEqg
 
There is some truth about what she says, but I want to give a balance perspective of her opinion.
 
Propnex has been pushing the sell one buy 2 strategy for years.  While I don't  advocate that myself, I know many Propnex agents do.  Many of my cobrokes are from Propnex and they are good agents.  A lot of their clients especially the early ones have benefited from that strategy and it has contributed greatly to the growth of Propnex from a local agency to now a SGX listed company.
 
But like any good strategy, it can be bad if it is overuse or not being assess carefully.  Panadol can be quite useful, but if you over consume it or use it in a wrong way, it can still be dangerous. The new agents who embark this strategy in social media now has to be careful  and skilled in financial planning before  recommendation because ABSD, stamp duty and even the deposit has all gone up quite significantly in terms of dollar value.
 
As for owning 34 properties kind of methods, please stay away. Trust me, I have probably attended much more of such seminars than the lady in the video above, and none of it is sound to me. I don't even want to discuss that path.
 
I like the fact that she raises some alarm on  these properties hype in social media ads.  But not all are bad please. I also use FB ads to promote my free ebook on what are the best bargains new launches today and it teaches how one can do simple valuation exercises to find good bargains. There is nothing snake oil in there.

https://sbr.com.sg/residential-property/news/amber-park-could-launch-sales-4-may
Amber Park could launch sales on 4 May
 

Amber Park by City Developments and Hong Realty opened its doors for viewing on the weekend. According to DBS Group Research, which visited the weekend viewings, the developer is confident to launch sales on 4 May with an indicative price starting from $2,160 psf.
 
DBS Group Research analyst Rachel Tan observed a steady crowd during her Sunday AM/PM visits. She said, “We understand that it was a lot more crowded on Saturday. Judging by the BMWs, Merc, Porsches and even a Maserati at the parking lots, we believe that the project launch has attracted the attention of the ‘well-heeled’ and discerning property buyers in Singapore.”

Its all about sustainability, and sometime avoid being the last one holding the baby when the music stops.
 
Music , from what I know has a habit of turning off immediately, while those that are holding the inventory are singing a different tune to say it simply slowing down, does not mean the music will stop, it wlll pick up again, just like every other year.
 
Most in the industry are starting to worry about some of the new launches and even more so by the lack of take up rate due to the cost of the land that was bidded.
 
While I do like the fact that any nearby plot of land is develop at a much higher rate and therefore, pushing up the prices for those that are owning the older property, it does no one any good if the bubble burst.
 
I would imagine the 1000PSF default benchmark would move to 1200psf YOY a 10 to 20% uplift. But is that sustainable.?
 
Unless wage growth has a componded increase, we are going to be the next australia and to a lesser extend, Malaysia.

Go to Acemundo's profileAcemundoMember's total reputation
 28,813
	
		14,730 posts

There is some truth about what she says, but I want to give a balance perspective of her opinion.
 
Propnex has been pushing the sell one buy 2 strategy for years.  While I don't  advocate that myself, I know many Propnex agents do.  Many of my cobrokes are from Propnex and they are good agents.  A lot of their clients especially the early ones have benefited from that strategy and it has contributed greatly to the growth of Propnex from a local agency to now a SGX listed company.
 
But like any good strategy, it can be bad if it is overuse or not being assess carefully.  Panadol can be quite useful, but if you over consume it or use it in a wrong way, it can still be dangerous. The new agents who embark this strategy in social media now has to be careful  and skilled in financial planning before  recommendation because ABSD, stamp duty and even the deposit has all gone up quite significantly in terms of dollar value.
 
As for owning 34 properties kind of methods, please stay away. Trust me, I have probably attended much more of such seminars than the lady in the video above, and none of it is sound to me. I don't even want to discuss that path.
 
I like the fact that she raises some alarm on  these properties hype in social media ads.  But not all are bad please. I also use FB ads to promote my free ebook on what are the best bargains new launches today and it teaches how one can do simple valuation exercises to find good bargains. There is nothing snake oil in there.

 
to be fair, when i shared the video, i also did not completely target the propnex agents.  what happens is the recently my facebook has been bombarded by the ads from these 2 self-styled property investor leader, Mark Ong and Germaine Chow (the one who claimed they owned 34 properties, and she was also featured in the sunday times invest column 3 weeks ago).  I got irritated, done some research and figured out what type of soup they are cooking up in their pot.  in fact their lineage can be traced back to another such self styled leader wendy kwek, who made a pile of money at the expenses of her investor followers.  i really cautioned all investors to fall for the glamourous marketing puffs and invest with these self-styled investor leader.
 
at the same time, i saw someone post this video link to debunk them and thought the video correctly sums up most of the gimmicky advertisement headlines in their ads.  it is unfortunate also that the propnex agents were mentioned in the same breath in the same video.  i had in fact been very close to 1 propnex agent who also helped me with such asset progression plan few.  hence, it is never in my intention to brand the propnex agents as scammers.  however, to be objective, i do feel the propnex agent tend to oversell this aspect of their service these days and became more focused on selling rather than planning for the capital appreciation for their clients.  for example, now almost every project kelvin fong and his entourage marketing, they also claims it is good buy.  i tend to disagree with them that there are so many good buys and felt they are guilty of churning to some extent.
by the way, which agency do you belong to?  i find you are one of the most objective real estate agent i have seen thus far.  you are neither too biased to sell as an agent nor too reticent in suggesting suitable timing and projects to look at.

Some will be more ethical. Others fear the consequences. 
A doctor can be taken to task for writing a memo to the wrong person.
A peeping tom can get a slap on the wrist.
A property agent? If he tell you the property will appreciate in value or that the price he is offering is rock bottom and it isn't, is there any recourse?
 
If not, then it will simply be his / her moral compass that determines whether he is ethical. And not all are.

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
I am not sure how fellow forummers will identify and agree with what I share here.
 
Personally, I feel that based on all traditional stats and calculations (income, GDP, employment, low or no corruption, sharing of economic benefits and growth), all classes of housing are underpriced in SG. HDB, condo, landed, all are underpriced at all locations (IMO).
 
When the inherent values are recognised and acknowledged resulting in price increases, the Govt wedges in cooling measures. Such measures may limit the growth of future selling prices of the properties bought, but they do not really affect the inherent worth or value of the property bought and adopted as a home or an investment instrument.
 
What a buyer needs to do is to understand his own situation thoroughly and identify the actual purpose of the purchase, and make the most optimal decision to buy the most underpriced property most optimised for her / her / their situations. To me, what's more important in buying SG property is self discovery rather than identify what is the best buy or when is the best time to buy according to experts. As one man's meat is another's poison, what is excellent for one might be unsuitable for another.
 
When one identifies and clarifies the actual intention and purpose for buying, then one goes into discovering the type, location and price of property most in line with that intention. The self-discovery stage, if omitted, will most likely result in huge disappointments even if one had the best buy ever.
 
For example, if I had opted for a FH landed some 7 years ago, my appreciation by last year should be larger as compared to the two condo units I had bought. But the rents from two condos consistently are higher than the landed, and my intention is to continue to deploy them for rental and modest appreciation for a good 10-20 years more. Moreover, by this year (2019), the appreciation plus rent of 2 condos (minus maintenance) has overcome the appreciation plus rent of that 1 landed.
 
But for one buying to stay, landed may indeed be a better choice. Or it might not due to other personal reasons. So embark on that journey of self-discovery soon to correctly evaluate all your choices.
 
 

to be fair, when i shared the video, i also did not completely target the propnex agents.  what happens is the recently my facebook has been bombarded by the ads from these 2 self-styled property investor leader, Mark Ong and Germaine Chow (the one who claimed they owned 34 properties, and she was also featured in the sunday times invest column 3 weeks ago).  I got irritated, done some research and figured out what type of soup they are cooking up in their pot.  in fact their lineage can be traced back to another such self styled leader wendy kwek, who made a pile of money at the expenses of her investor followers.  i really cautioned all investors to fall for the glamourous marketing puffs and invest with these self-styled investor leader.at the same time, i saw someone post this video link to debunk them and thought the video correctly sums up most of the gimmicky advertisement headlines in their ads.  it is unfortunate also that the propnex agents were mentioned in the same breath in the same video.  i had in fact been very close to 1 propnex agent who also helped me with such asset progression plan few.  hence, it is never in my intention to brand the propnex agents as scammers.  however, to be objective, i do feel the propnex agent tend to oversell this aspect of their service these days and became more focused on selling rather than planning for the capital appreciation for their clients.  for example, now almost every project kelvin fong and his entourage marketing, they also claims it is good buy.  i tend to disagree with them that there are so many good buys and felt they are guilty of churning to some extent.
by the way, which agency do you belong to?  i find you are one of the most objective real estate agent i have seen thus far.  you are neither too biased to sell as an agent nor too reticent in suggesting suitable timing and projects to look at.

actually i am mostly agreeing with you.  that properties in singapore are by and large undervalued and having room to appreciate.
 
what i don't agree is with the agents calling buys on all properties they market at all times.  the investor has limited resources, they can only afford to buy 1 property say over the next 10 years.  hence, it would be more proper for the property advisor to help pick a reasonably good time for a good buy instead of advising like as if all the time is good for investing and almost all properties are similarly good for capital appreciation and also not putting absd considerations into the equation for advice.

Didn't wanna watch those videos. 
 
Those claiming to own 34 properties with little downpayment, how do they claim to do that?

@kusje  @showster
that's what i guess they do:
 
1) buy industrial or commercial property because no absd
2) old industrial property are quite cheap, because the remaining lease very short, could cost $500k only
3) leverage and maximise loan on these property.  loan to valuation for such properties are way higher than residential.that is how they achieved "little or no money down"
4) some of the properties may be parked under a company owned by few shareholders.  so although they could be owning only 10% of 1 property, they can lay claim to owning 10 properties (of 10% each)
5) for those that claimed they upgrade to landed house or porsche, my guess is that they already have the means to buy such property on their own accord.  they only lend their story to the advertiser to help them due to their close friendship
6) some of the old industrial property could indeed fetch 6-7% rent now..but take note that low potential of capital appreciation and if can't find tenant, it will be a costly investment instead
7) the sunday times on last sunday, featured some individual buyers of medical suite offices thinking they could earn steady stream of lucrative rental income but got burnt because cannot find tenants.

In stocks, it stands for Do Your Own Due Diligence. An agent will never be able to advise if the space is sufficient for you, whether and how many family members should stay with you, how long you should or intend to hold on to the property, etc etc.
 
Even the so-called "expensive" BUC (new) properties could be value propositions depending on the intention of deployment.
 
To be honest, I bought at times when the PSF of a new property are pretty close to the surrounding resales options. That was why I chose what I chose.

at the same time, i saw someone post this video link to debunk them and thought the video correctly sums up most of the gimmicky advertisement headlines in their ads.  it is unfortunate also that the propnex agents were mentioned in the same breath in the same video.  i had in fact been very close to 1 propnex agent who also helped me with such asset progression plan few.  hence, it is never in my intention to brand the propnex agents as scammers.  however, to be objective, i do feel the propnex agent tend to oversell this aspect of their service these days and became more focused on selling rather than planning for the capital appreciation for their clients.  for example, now almost every project kelvin fong and his entourage marketing, they also claims it is good buy.  i tend to disagree with them that there are so many good buys and felt they are guilty of churning to some extent.

It is good that the snake oil peddlers get exposed. I have no issue with that.
 
As for me, I am not from Propnex.  It doesn't matter where I am from but I appreciate your comments abt me. However, "being objective" often does not translate to income in this industry.  People loves shiny objects like "how to buy 34 properties" and think value-analysis (which I specialise in and is a proven sound method in optimal wealth creation for property investment) is boring.   But I stand firm on my objectivity and ethics. It is better to make less money than to go to bed not able to sleep.
 
Anyway the sell 1 buy 2 strategy is not easy to implement thesedays because of the higher upfront cost due to CM. If any agents are to peddle that, ask for the full financial status and mortgage repayment schedule for each of the buyer (often husband and wife). If the report look sound, ask to cut the estimated loan amount by 15% and see if it is still viable to buy a suitable property for both. I have a software that simulates this strategy. I don't actively advocate this strategy but because clients always ask, I took the trouble to find a vendor who sell such software (with updated CM measures)  so that I can check for them for free before they get hype up by this strategy.
 
Whether sell 1 buy 2 or sell 1 buy 1, the key is not the strategy. The key is whether did you buy at fair/good value? Ask your agent to justify value for whatever they are selling. And please don't accept reasons like next door is selling $xxx psf so this property at $yyy must be good value. That's pure nonsense unless he can show that both $xxx psf and $yyy psf are not  overprice to begin with.

It is better to make less money than to go to bed not able to sleep.
 
Anyway the sell 1 buy 2 strategy is not easy to implement thesedays because of the higher upfront cost due to CM. If any agents are to peddle that, ask for the full financial status and mortgage repayment schedule for each of the buyer (often husband and wife). If the report look sound, ask to cut the estimated loan amount by 15% and see if it is still viable to buy a suitable property for both. I have a software that simulates this strategy. I don't actively advocate this strategy but because clients always ask, I took the trouble to find a vendor who sell such software (with updated CM measures)  so that I can check for them for free before they get hype up by this strategy.
 
Whether sell 1 buy 2 or sell 1 buy 1, the key is not the strategy. The key is whether did you buy at fair/good value? Ask your agent to justify value for whatever they are selling. And please don't accept reasons like next door is selling $xxx psf so this property at $yyy must be good value. That's pure nonsense unless he can show that both $xxx psf and $yyy psf are not  overprice to begin with.

 
yes, there is a cantonese idiom that has it if one is too honest and ethical, one ends up not able to bring home the bacon..unfortunate but sad fact in life.  but still i agree with you that it is better to earn less and be able to sleep during bedtime knowing you have not misled your customers into a bad choice of purchase.
 
hehe on your last para, yes there is a lot of half baked snake-oil peddling agents who simply use such line of reasoning to convince us to buy or sell........

https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/singhaiyi’s-gazania-and-lilium-sell-15-launched-units-over-first-day-sales
SingHaiyi’s The Gazania and The Lilium sell 15% of launched units over first day of sales
 

Singapore-listed property developer SingHaiyi Group has announced that it has sold 23 units (15%) out of 165 units that were launched for sale from its twin residential projects – The Gazania and The Lilium. The first day of sales over the Labour Day holiday attracted more than 200 prospective home buyers for the balloting.
 
The 250-unit The Gazania features one- to four-bedroom unit types including four-bedroom maisonette units, while the 80-unit The Lilium comprises two- to four-bedroom units and penthouses. Larger-sized units saw more interest from home owners, with more than 70% of the home buyers purchasing three- to four-bedroom units, including a penthouse unit.

https://www.msn.com/en-sg/news/singapore/singaporeans-spend-triple-the-time-searching-for-property-than-reading-their-children-bedtime-stories-or-speaking-to-their-parents-hsbc-study/ar-AAAMSZB?li=AAaGkVj&%252525252525253Bocid=mailsignoutmd
 
Singaporeans spend triple the time searching for property than reading their children bedtime stories or speaking to their parents
 
Calling property a “national sport for Singaporeans”, HSBC said on Thursday (May 2) that its Beyond the Bricks 2019 survey found that Singaporeans spend 3.29 hours every week on property-related window shopping. That includes searching for property online and reading property magazines even when they are not looking to buy a new home.
In comparison, the respondents spent just slightly more than an hour (1.03 hour) reading their children bedtime stories, and less than an hour (0.94 hour) talking to their parents every week.
The global survey of 11,000 people across 10 countries and territories, including 1,000 respondents in Singapore, polled respondents on their attitudes towards home ownership and financing a home.
Not only are Singaporeans highly active property shoppers, a large 75 per cent of first-time home buyers view five or less homes before deciding on one.
Slightly more than one-third (36 per cent) are impulsive and buy properties based purely on first impressions. This is lower than the global 39 per cent.
 
Impulse purchases are even more pronounced among extreme Singaporean property addicts who spend over 7 hours a week reading about or researching property, HSBC said. Around 51 per cent of these “addicts” admit to buying a property on first sight while 63 per cent of them did not have any criteria to adhere to when shopping for a property.

Edited May 3 by Sdf4786k

Go to Acemundo's profileAcemundoMember's total reputation
 28,813
	
		14,730 posts

My take is that developers with lower land cost will still sell around the same price as their higher cost competitors.
They also have 5 years to decide if they should price lower.
Basically kicking the can down further.

 
 
yes, which brings me back to my experience previously with the agents marketing echelon back in 2012/2013.  when i visited the showroom, they were showing me all the land bid price comparison of their project, vs Alex Residences and The Crest.  i feel their marketing talk is somewhat underhanded, as they keep asking me how much premium Alex and The Crest will sell over Echelon given the premium they paid in land bid prices over Echelon. bearing the brunt of their attack is the Alex, because its land bid price is close to 200psfppr above that of Echelon.  nevertheless, i didn't buy echelon nor alex nor the crest.  but from hindsight now, i can definitely say, alex selling price in psf terms is actually quite close to Echelon prices.  put simply, the so-called projected premium selling price didn't materialise mainly because their developer sold at much lower margin because the timing of their launch is less favourable than Echelon.  It does show that land bid price doesn't have a direct correlation to the selling price, especially given that the time of winning the bid vs the time of sales launch would still have a window period of several months.  it only shows that developers are profit maximisation driven and will price the highest possible when it can still move units, while land bid price sets the floor, it doesn't set the selling price. 
Go to Wind30's profileWind30Member's total reputation
 7,358
	
		3,491 posts

My take is that developers with lower land cost will still sell around the same price as their higher cost competitors.
They also have 5 years to decide if they should price lower.
Basically kicking the can down further.

Go to Khng8's profileKhng8Member's total reputation
 631
	
		267 posts
The developers may not have confidence to price higher than the market price now. But does not mean they will sell lower now. Until the situation turns for the worse or they are forced to (eg ABSD deadline).
 
And they want enbloc prices to be much lower than what sellers are prepared to sell for now to give bigger margin of error. Hence the standstill.
 
If they get their land cheap, they need not sell cheap too.
 
Because if one developer breaks ranks & sell lower, the neighbouring project may have to write down their project, triggering a wave of marked to market adjustment.
 
No one wants to be the bad guy.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-02-21/the-real-crazy-rich-asian-palace-is-worth-a-cool-3-5-billion
 
 
In the heart of Singapore, one of the most expensive cities in the world, there’s a sprawling, vacant plot of private land 30 times the size of The White House.
Just down the road from the U.S. embassy and bordering condos worth S$4.5 million ($3.3 million) each, the swathe of untended jungle hides the remains of two abandoned palaces and would be worth a cool $3.5 billion if sold for development, according to one estimate. In a city where almost 8,000 people are crammed into each square kilometer and real estate prices are among the world’s highest, it is one of the greatest urban anachronisms in Asia.

Go to Icedbs's profileIcedbsMember's total reputation
 16,579
	
		6,254 posts

Waiting for a crash may be difficult to predict and hard to time..
but keep your ammo ready if you are ready to commit.

 
The key is not to wait for crash. 
 
The key is to learn how to identify value and buy only those.
 
In my line, I met so many owners who buy based on hype and emotions. They have no idea how to find value thinking that value = the value the bank is willing to give loan. 
 
In today's market, there are so many resale units selling  at good value. For savvy buyers, it is boom time.
 
For new launches, there are quite a few selling at good value. But most are overprice. You just need to know which ones.

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
Waiting for crash in an unregulated (near 0 cooling measures) environment (1997, 2002, 2008 for example) has proven to be rather fruitful for those who can wait.
 
But waiting for crash in an environment laden thick with cooling measures is really a futile exercise. If the bull can still tiptoe forward chained, whipped and strapped, what does it tell us about its inherent vitality?
 
The inflexibility and rigidity will cause many golden opportunities to be lost.

Amber Park in East Coast sells 115 of 150 units at $2,425 psf in weekend launch
 

The take-up was "the strongest launch weekend sales for a freehold project this year"
 
The sold units - which included a penthouse - amounted to a total sales value of over $240 million and covered all apartment types.
 
About 85 per cent of the buyers were Singaporeans, while the remaining were foreigners mainly from China, Malaysia, Indonesia, India and others.

Neither an owner nor agent
But was there at echelon launch (very memorable because of the huge crowd, lucky draw, heavy rain and lighting that day) and after its TOP
Units were sold at profits at TOP, that what agents said then  
Very surprised because units were bought a very high pfs, if recall correctly, verified two units and turned out to be true
 
Even for last 6 months, there were 4 profits vs 3 losses (source:squarefoot research)
 
Echelon, well built and very solid (externally), finishing inside units was generally good. 
 
On hind side, those who bought at those high pfs probably made a decent investment
 
The point is that there are so many factors involved in prices among condos that are of similar age in same area
 
Echelon was one of the first of several condos in that redhill belt. Despite high pfs, prices have generally held quite up well because of the development quality and convenience and MRT. 
 
For Crest, other than bigger units, one issue with some buyers is one has to cross the bridge/road to get to MRT

Since we are discussing about Echelon, let me reveal a few more data
 
In 2012 a year before Echelon started selling,  D3 LH has an avg $psf of $1317
 
Then Echelon started selling in January 2013 at avg $1794 psf for the whole of  2013
 
That's a 36% premium over the District just a year before. With CM in place, there is no way they are going to have good appreciation between 5-10 years when the premium is 36%!
 
Now, if we look at Amber Park, average $psf for D15 FH/999 today is $1566. Amber Park is $2425. 
 
I leave it to you guys to calculate the premium here and draw conclusion yourself. Maybe these investors knew something that I do not know.

 28,813
	
		14,730 posts

Since we are discussing about Echelon, let me reveal a few more data
 
In 2012 a year before Echelon started selling,  D3 LH has an avg $psf of $1317
 
Then Echelon started selling in January 2013 at avg $1794 psf for the whole of  2013
 
That's a 36% premium over the District just a year before. With CM in place, there is no way they are going to have good appreciation between 5-10 years when the premium is 36%!
 
Now, if we look at Amber Park, average $psf for D15 FH/999 today is $1566. Amber Park is $2425. 
 
I leave it to you guys to calculate the premium here and draw conclusion yourself. Maybe these investors knew something that I do not know.

to be fair to brother @car50, indeed squarefoot does show 4 profitable transactions vs 3 unprofitable transactions.  i must admit i am surprised some of the profitable units had lower purchase price than i thought.  now but i had another doubt.
 
i thought i had set the filter to include all transactions.  does it mean that from day 1 till now, there are only 4 profitable transactions vs 3 unprofitable ones?  if yes, then i would still think the echelon is far from a good buy reasoning being:
 
1) it has been good 2 year after plus after ssd expires and there are only 4 profitable transactions
2) there is inherent bias in such statistics gathered because most people would only sell when there is profit while those who sell despite a loss would be number lower because they are forced by circumstances to sell.
3) even if we disregard 2 points above, i would say 4 profitable vs 3 unprofitable transactions over time still means it is lower in terms of profitability.  for example, the much maligned alex residences already had 1 profitable (vs 0 unprofitable) despite a shorter window of about 2 years compared to echelon.

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
We are in a state of very highly distorted property market currently.
 
i.e. it is not a free market.
 
The transactions on the market do not fully or even well reflect the prices that all buyers and sellers are willing and able to transact at.
 
Give you an example...
 
Let's say buying a handphone sold at unregulated market prices. Buyers can choose and move between sellers until they find the correct match in terms of brand, price, warranty and condition of phone etc. Sellers set their respective prices and wait for buyers.
 
In current private property market, relatively few qualified buyers exist in terms of capability to buy (with sufficient savings, enbloc proceeds and supporting income) and in terms of willingness to buy (willing to pay all the taxes for example.
 
The sellers on the other hand have holding power (clearing TDSR or developers with huge pockets), and are generally not willing to sell (those who wanted to sell would not even have considered buying easily). The only group selling are those who are forced to (emigration, downgrading, upgrading, forced circumstances) or are holding "inferior" products (very old properties or some specific issues with their property - similar to cars with 3-4 owners)
 
The actual transactions in this very highly distorted market are very misleading to depend on as a guide for market condition.
 
 

to be fair to brother @car50, indeed squarefoot does show 4 profitable transactions vs 3 unprofitable transactions.  i must admit i am surprised some of the profitable units had lower purchase price than i thought.  now but i had another doubt.
 
i thought i had set the filter to include all transactions.  does it mean that from day 1 till now, there are only 4 profitable transactions vs 3 unprofitable ones?  if yes, then i would still think the echelon is far from a good buy reasoning being:
 
1) it has been good 2 year after plus after ssd expires and there are only 4 profitable transactions2) there is inherent bias in such statistics gathered because most people would only sell when there is profit while those who sell despite a loss would be number lower because they are forced by circumstances to sell.3) even if we disregard 2 points above, i would say 4 profitable vs 3 unprofitable transactions over time still means it is lower in terms of profitability.  for example, the much maligned alex residences already had 1 profitable (vs 0 unprofitable) despite a shorter window of about 2 years compared to echelon.

We are in a state of very highly distorted property market currently.
 
i.e. it is not a free market.
 
The transactions on the market do not fully or even well reflect the prices that all buyers and sellers are willing and able to transact at.
 
Give you an example...
 
Let's say buying a handphone sold at unregulated market prices. Buyers can choose and move between sellers until they find the correct match in terms of brand, price, warranty and condition of phone etc. Sellers set their respective prices and wait for buyers.
 
In current private property market, relatively few qualified buyers exist in terms of capability to buy (with sufficient savings, enbloc proceeds and supporting income) and in terms of willingness to buy (willing to pay all the taxes for example.
 
The sellers on the other hand have holding power (clearing TDSR or developers with huge pockets), and are generally not willing to sell (those who wanted to sell would not even have considered buying easily). The only group selling are those who are forced to (emigration, downgrading, upgrading, forced circumstances) or are holding "inferior" products (very old properties or some specific issues with their property - similar to cars with 3-4 owners)
 
The actual transactions in this very highly distorted market are very misleading to depend on as a guide for market condition.

 
i agree.  that's why there were 3 of us who thought that echelon is a poor buy (while there was 1 who thought echelon is a good buy) because of the considerations of the ssd and absd dragging down the likelihood of profitability for a pricey project.  and also in my pointers, i established that there will be, by laws of nature, more profitable than non-profitable transactions and the dearth of transactions, actually shows a lot more owners are stuck because their unit sale would have render them under water in current market.

Go to Enye's profileEnyeMember's total reputation
 67,366
	
		13,384 posts
wah...any agent here can confirm or is fake news?
 
  
 
  Monday, 6 May 2019
	Developer SPH and Kajima Slashed Woodleigh Residences Price by 10%-13% from $2000psf to starting from $1733psf For Relaunch in May 2019. 


Interestingly today, my property agent messaged me that Singapore Press Holdings ("SPH") and its partner Kajima had slashed the price of Woodleigh Residences by 10% to 13% from S$2,000psf to as low as S$1,733psf. This was despite their initial assertion that the VVIP launch in October 2018 was a resounding success with over 60% of the launched units sold at an average price of 2,000psf. However, for the re-launch of Woodleigh Residences in May 2019, the developer SPH and Kajima must have decided that the risk of the market downturn may not be worth it and started slashing prices drastically in order to move more units. After all, the developer was only able to sell 30 units on the first weekend of its initial launch albeit declaring that 60% were sold by proclaiming that they only launched 50 units.  
 
For a 958sqft 3 bedder unit, prices would have dropped from S$1.92Mil to S$1.66Mil which translates to substantial savings of +S$256K for potential buyers relative to the first batch of VVIP. This does not seem fair to those first batch of buyers who had supported this integrated mixed commercial and residential project of SPH and Kajima during launch. I hope that SPH and Kajima would have given some goodwill renovation packages to compensate these initial buyers. 
 
On the property market front, I am not sure whether other developers will also take the lead in slashing prices but I hope so for the benefit of consumers. Once the music stops, property developers holding on to the most unsold inventories would need a very strong balance sheet to wait out the economic downturn. 
 
From the stock investing perspective, I have previously highlighted the lingering impairment risk of the Bidadari project, that is, Woodleigh Residences, due to the potential property market downturn and uncleared inventories.  I am glad that SPH has decided to slash the price in order to move their inventory of unsold units. Coupled with the bad news from the US/China trade war today, SPH price has dropped to S$2.40 per share and it may be worthwhile to re-look into their newly transformed property business from the previous media giant model. The new UK student accommodation segment acquisition should prove invaluable in the event of an economic downturn due to earnings resiliency

wah...any agent here can confirm or is fake news?
 
 
 
Monday, 6 May 2019


 
	Developer SPH and Kajima Slashed Woodleigh Residences Price by 10%-13% from $2000psf to starting from $1733psf For Relaunch in May 2019.
 

 

Interestingly today, my property agent messaged me that Singapore Press Holdings ("SPH") and its partner Kajima had slashed the price of Woodleigh Residences by 10% to 13% from S$2,000psf to as low as S$1,733psf. This was despite their initial assertion that the VVIP launch in October 2018 was a resounding success with over 60% of the launched units sold at an average price of 2,000psf. However, for the re-launch of Woodleigh Residences in May 2019, the developer SPH and Kajima must have decided that the risk of the market downturn may not be worth it and started slashing prices drastically in order to move more units. After all, the developer was only able to sell 30 units on the first weekend of its initial launch albeit declaring that 60% were sold by proclaiming that they only launched 50 units.   
For a 958sqft 3 bedder unit, prices would have dropped from S$1.92Mil to S$1.66Mil which translates to substantial savings of +S$256K for potential buyers relative to the first batch of VVIP. This does not seem fair to those first batch of buyers who had supported this integrated mixed commercial and residential project of SPH and Kajima during launch. I hope that SPH and Kajima would have given some goodwill renovation packages to compensate these initial buyers. 
 
On the property market front, I am not sure whether other developers will also take the lead in slashing prices but I hope so for the benefit of consumers. Once the music stops, property developers holding on to the most unsold inventories would need a very strong balance sheet to wait out the economic downturn. 
 
From the stock investing perspective, I have previously highlighted the lingering impairment risk of the Bidadari project, that is, Woodleigh Residences, due to the potential property market downturn and uncleared inventories.  I am glad that SPH has decided to slash the price in order to move their inventory of unsold units. Coupled with the bad news from the US/China trade war today, SPH price has dropped to S$2.40 per share and it may be worthwhile to re-look into their newly transformed property business from the previous media giant model. The new UK student accommodation segment acquisition should prove invaluable in the event of an economic downturn due to earnings resiliency

Sifu 就是 Sifu

wah...any agent here can confirm or is fake news?
 
 
 
 
Monday, 6 May 2019 Developer SPH and Kajima Slashed Woodleigh Residences Price by 10%-13% from $2000psf to starting from $1733psf For Relaunch in May 2019. 


Interestingly today, my property agent messaged me that Singapore Press Holdings ("SPH") and its partner Kajima had slashed the price of Woodleigh Residences by 10% to 13% from S$2,000psf to as low as S$1,733psf. This was despite their initial assertion that the VVIP launch in October 2018 was a resounding success with over 60% of the launched units sold at an average price of 2,000psf. However, for the re-launch of Woodleigh Residences in May 2019, the developer SPH and Kajima must have decided that the risk of the market downturn may not be worth it and started slashing prices drastically in order to move more units. After all, the developer was only able to sell 30 units on the first weekend of its initial launch albeit declaring that 60% were sold by proclaiming that they only launched 50 units.  
 
For a 958sqft 3 bedder unit, prices would have dropped from S$1.92Mil to S$1.66Mil which translates to substantial savings of +S$256K for potential buyers relative to the first batch of VVIP. This does not seem fair to those first batch of buyers who had supported this integrated mixed commercial and residential project of SPH and Kajima during launch. I hope that SPH and Kajima would have given some goodwill renovation packages to compensate these initial buyers. 
 
On the property market front, I am not sure whether other developers will also take the lead in slashing prices but I hope so for the benefit of consumers. Once the music stops, property developers holding on to the most unsold inventories would need a very strong balance sheet to wait out the economic downturn. 
 
From the stock investing perspective, I have previously highlighted the lingering impairment risk of the Bidadari project, that is, Woodleigh Residences, due to the potential property market downturn and uncleared inventories.  I am glad that SPH has decided to slash the price in order to move their inventory of unsold units. Coupled with the bad news from the US/China trade war today, SPH price has dropped to S$2.40 per share and it may be worthwhile to re-look into their newly transformed property business from the previous media giant model. The new UK student accommodation segment acquisition should prove invaluable in the event of an economic downturn due to earnings resiliency

Go to therock's profiletherockMember's total reputation
 25,983
	
		7,828 posts
https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/some-commercial-buildings-finding-it-hard-to-sell-en-bloc
 
 
Not all smooth sailing 
So this could be a sign for the many buildings along Balestier and other spots with mixed use buildings.. 
 

 
Some commercial buildings are facing an uphill task trying to achieve collective sales, with buyers deterred by high retail vacancy rates and prohibitive selling prices.
One of the more recent candidates for such a sale is Queensway Shopping Centre, a 45-year-old freehold site known for its sporting goods, but it has been far from smooth sailing.
An April 20 meeting to obtain consent for the move found that many owners were opposed to selling.
One is tailor Simon Chong, who is unimpressed by the $480,000 being offered for his 106 sq ft store.
He said in Mandarin: "It's a freehold space and we have our regular customers. Why would I want to sell it?"
The Straits Times understands that shop owners, who collectively account for more than 20 per cent of the property's share value, have joined forces to oppose the deal.
 
 
Rising numbers of commercial and mixed-use developments have hopped on the bandwagon since 2017, including landmarks such as People's Park Centre, Golden Mile Complex and Sim Lim Square.
However, such projects usually see a lower success rate than their residential counterparts.

https://www.propertyguru.com.sg/property-management-news/2019/5/179892/5-room-hdb-flat-in-bukit-merah-sold-for-record-1-2m
5-Room HDB Flat In Bukit Merah Sold For Record $1.2m
 

A standard 5-room HDB flat was sold for $1.2 million in April this year – the first time that a standard HDB flat price surpassed the most expensive non-standard flats (DBSS units, terraces, maisonettes or flats at Pinnacle@Duxton) ever sold.
 
It smashed the previous records set by a 5-room DBSS unit at Boon Keng Road sold in January this year and a 237 sq m HDB Terrace at Jalan Bahagia in September 2018, both of which were sold at $1.185 million.
