Edited July 26 by sgcarmart2019

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts

the examples in your table is all lh99 not fh leh
you got mistaken la
how can our government compensated fh owners at lh99 price
The examples in Bala’s table are all computed based on land value as a proportion of FH value. 
So a LH with 99 years left will have 96% value of FH land.
 
That means even if you paid 20% more to secure the FH land, when Govt pays for your land, the most you can expect them to pay is fresh 99LH plus 4%.
 
FH is still tagged to LH values.
 
If you read the table carefully, you will also realise that LH with 60 years lease left still has 80% land value as freehold.
 
Therefore if someone chose a new 99LH, by saving up 20% costs at time of purchase upfront, he will get 20% less at the time of compensation some 40 years down the road.
 
Voluntary enbloc, indeed can fight for 10-20% premium with Developers. But when compulsorily acquired, the premium for land is at most 4% over a comparable site GLS offering.

The examples in Balaâs table are all computed based on land value as a proportion of FH value.
 
So a LH with 99 years left will have 96% value of FH land.
 
That means even if you paid 20% more to secure the FH land, when Govt pays for your land, the most you can expect them to pay is fresh 99LH plus 4%.
 
FH is still tagged to LH values.
 
If you read the table carefully, you will also realise that LH with 60 years lease left still has 80% land value as freehold.
 
Therefore if someone chose a new 99LH, by saving up 20% costs at time of purchase upfront, he will get 20% less at the time of compensation some 40 years down the road.

		7,828 posts
Seems like the HKGers prefer some other places to SG to settle down ..
https://www.straitstimes.com/world/americas/hong-kongers-scout-properties-in-canada-and-uk-to-escape-protests
 

 
TORONTO (BLOOMBERG) - As protests continue to rock Hong Kong, real estate brokers in Canada and the UK are fielding a flood of inquiries from investors in the former British colony who are eager to get out.
Mr Dan Scarrow, president of Macdonald Real Estate Group in Vancouver, said many of his Chinese agents saw an uptick in interest for both sales and rentals this month from Hong Kong. One of his agents is putting off her planned retirement this year to capitalise on the opportunity.
Before, it was usually a ratio of five mainland Chinese to one Hong Kong buyer coming to open houses, he said.
"It has completely flipped now," said Mr Scarrow. "Whether or not that actually translates into deals, that comes down to what continues to happen in Hong Kong."
People have begun scouting for properties in cities, including Toronto, Vancouver and London, as the unease surrounding Hong Kong's political future grows amid China's increasing influence. A drop in residential property prices is making some of these cities attractive.
"Hong Kong money could become a major source of capital," said Mr David Ho, a broker at CBRE who deals with Asian investments. "People are shocked, given that Hong Kong was always branded as a stable, rule-of-law financial hub, and now want to move their capital to other cities to mitigate the risk and also to look for other homes."
 
 
A look at few of the markets that are of interest to the Hong Kong buyers: Vancouver's Advantage Vancouver, where housing prices have been in a slump for the past year, may be the first city to benefit from the upheaval in Hong Kong.
 
Changes in Vancouver tax laws have pushed property prices lower since 2018, Knight Frank said in a report, adding that investors will also benefit from currency-adjusted discounts of 17 per cent over the last year.

		6,254 posts

Thats very surprising. I always have the belief that BTO flats is 100% sure made $$ one.
What makes you say there is little gain?

 
Punggol and SengKang, the two most popular BTO areas have 132 units that are going to MOP within the next 1 month.
 
Out of these 132 units, only 16 units are in the black based on market valuation.
 
And out of that 16 units that probably make money, only 2 units could be between 10%-20% profit. The other 14 units are all below 10% profit.
 
But note that 116 units are all under water.
 
That's new BTO for you.

Punggol and SengKang, the two most popular BTO areas have 132 units that are going to MOP within the next 1 month.

Actually i kind of understand the feeling of these hdb upgraders.
 
The HDB resale seems to be going south while the private is going higher. That is why they are willing to sell at a loss now so they can upgrade to private ASAP. They are worried that every year they delay, the gap is just going to get bigger. 
 
That is why I always thing HDB prices should be benchmarked to private resale and the government has to keep private property prices in checked. This allows citizens to achieve their dream of owning a private property.

		5,886 posts
It is not a must and/or every citizen's right to be upgraded to private housing.
 
In many cases, it's because they booked a private first then intend to sell off HDB when TOP, and they have to do within half a year so as to qualify for remission of ABSD.
 
Loss also sell, if not they pay for the loss with ABSD. Some in the end chose to keep both and chose to forgo ABSD remission instead.
 

Actually i kind of understand the feeling of these hdb upgraders.
 
The HDB resale seems to be going south while the private is going higher. That is why they are willing to sell at a loss now so they can upgrade to private ASAP. They are worried that every year they delay, the gap is just going to get bigger. 
 
That is why I always think HDB prices should be benchmarked to private resale and the government has to keep private property prices in checked. This allows citizens to achieve their dream of owning a private property.

Are HDB resale prices really going south?
 
depend 
if atas location, good facing good view, high floor, near mrt , near town near amenities, then price is UP UP UP
eg high floors at dbss boon keng, pinnacle duxton , peak tpy, etc
 
sadly most of hdbs do not fulfill above criteria hence overall hdb resale trend now is downwards, especially those old ones more than 30yr and lousy locations or poor facing
Go to sgcarmart2019's profilesgcarmart2019Member's total reputation
 119
	
		285 posts

wah...no private condo means no achievement and no dream
 
 

 
pte condo alot of cheap affordable ones, eg those in the range $1100 to $1400psf are consider mass market pte condo
guideline quantum for these units about ~$1.5mil for 3room (~1000 to 1200sqf)
this range is consider stepping stone for hdb upgraders due to the affordable quantum for a $9,500 median household income and tdsr 60%, meaning for a median income family, max loan is $5700pm including all debts (house, car, personal loan, credit card loan, etc)
 
above this is mid range, $1400psf to $1800psf
 
go higher is mid-high , around $1900psf to $2400psf, quantum about ~$2mil for a 1000 to 1200sqf unit
 
go even higher is high range $2500psf to $3000psf
 
luxury range is above $3000psf, eg the dyson 21000sqf penthouse is 73mil, ie $3450psf

in as early as possible for fh or new lh99 is ok la, if in as early as possible for a old lh99 hdb or pte which no enbloc taker or no resale potential and depreciation to zero at 99th year also sad storyAs mentioned prior, no one size fits all, diff folks diff requirements.Today, whether buying for own stay/rental yield/capital appreciation, I would pick a old resale LH over new launch 99lh.
 
-New units new lease 99, but then you are also paying for it at high psf.
-Old units less lease years, you also pay less psf/overall quantum.
 
'Go resale for better value'
 
 

EC is special breed, not anyone eligible. For those who want brand new condo, even at record sale psf, still the lowest around compared to private.
 
Personally if buying, I won't even bother with new launches today. High selling psf for new LH, can get resale FH.
Above 1k psf for new EC, can get resale private condo in a better location near to mrt...etc 
'Go resale for better value' 
 
That said, diff strokes diff folks. Just like some willing to pay record price for resale HDB 
 
https://sg.finance.yahoo.com/news/resale-record-set-dbss-unit-053000714.html
New resale record set by DBSS unit at City View @ Boon Keng


Reasons why FH gaining popularity, high psf of new 99LH, can get resale FH.
The other is due to last enbloc fever of FH projects, FH land is a thing of the past, all GLS is 99, if no enbloc where to find FH?
HDB/PTE different ball game, for PTE can enbloc top up lease to fresh 99. FH LH both got pro and con. Example FH not be in as good location as LH,next to mrt etc.
 
As mentioned prior, same principles apply can rent out either the hdb/pte 30 years cost more or less covered, still have 70 years to go 'FREE', which is a very loooooooong time. 
If concern of lease run down,can adopt appropriate approach at different stages of the 99 years.Example, sell within first 10-20 years.
 
Without enbloc, all future new launches to be only LH. For me, I won't be too duly concerned about it. High sell psf for new launches, I see more 'value' in resale, and those new 99 will eventually be older resale too. So even for old 20-30 years LH resales, may represent a 'value' buy whether own stay or rental capital appreciation investment.
Example, buying old resale own stay just put in 50-100k reno to 'brand new'. Buying for rental, lower cost pay less interest to bank higher yield etc.
 
Again, 99 years is a very long time can cover 2 generations. For the buyer, probably won't even have the chance to see lease running down to zero.
'Go resale for better value'

1.5m quantum seem like the norm now for a entry level mass market lh99 pte condo 3br
eg if the 3br unit is 1100sqf , 1.5mil means its $1400psf

currently median h/h income is about $9500per mth, so if tdsr is 60%, means total debt payable per month for this household is $5700
say a household buy a 1.5mil pte condo down 20%, borrow 80% for 25yr at 2.6% interest, the bank loan is 1.2mil, monthly payment to bank is $5400

By 2030 LTA masterplan say 80% of household will be within 10 mins walk to a mrt station... I estimate 10 mins to be about 600m..
 
If 8 in 10 have this access it means that 
 
1. If you are not within 600m your apartment / condo is considered very inconvenient 
 
2. If you are within 600m u are just one of the 80%
 
3. If you are within 300m and 5 mins walk the apartment is considered desirable
 
4. If within 200m and 3 mins walk then super super hot!
 
5. If within 200-300m and there is a mall there as well and FH!!! This is the ultimate already must keep long long

Go to Alfc's profileAlfcMember's total reputation
 1,319
	
		665 posts

old pte lh99 in lousy locations may be falling
but new LH99 and FH in good locations are going up
shows that buyers are now selective of choice properties that can hedge against inflation

If inflation is at 3% p.a, effectively a $1m LH99 property today needs to sell out at $1.8m 20 years later (with 78 yrs lease remaining) just to match.
 
Anything less than 30% capital appreciation 20 years later (based on 50% upfront, BSD, ABSD, conveyances, today's gross rental yield 3%, 2% loan,5k per year property-related expenses), one would be in no better off than just to put the current cash upfront in a relatively do-nothing risk-free type of 1.8% return (SSB, ETFs, term insurance etc). There are so many variables that can swing the equation for property ownership vs just 1 for the fixed income investment.
 
Not saying dun buy or disputing property uptrend but one got to do the sums. Not a sure win for just any purchase which is already mentioned by many here.

eg if the 3br unit is 1100sqf , 1.5mil means its $1400psf
 
notwithstanding, even ulu location EC direct from hdb now already hit $1080psf !!
 
btw i guess mass mkt quantum is always pegged to median household income
 
currently median h/h income is about $9500per mth, so if tdsr is 60%, means total debt payable per month for this household is $5700
say a household buy a 1.5mil pte condo down 20%, borrow 80% for 25yr at 2.6% interest, the bank loan is 1.2mil, monthly payment to bank is $5400
Nowadays where got down 20%? 
Govt says down 25% minimum.
 
Later if property run continues unabated, down 30% on the way..
 
Run slowly.

Hong Kongers are coming:
https://www.asiaone.com/asia/singapore-becomes-option-hongkongers-amid-political-crisis
"His clients - mostly families with one or two children - often came with a budget of between S$5 million and S$20 million, and opted for listings in prime residential areas such as Singapore's shopping district, Orchard Road.
The latest government figures show Singapore's private home prices are on the rise, but even for those with smaller budgets and despite the additional buyers' stamp duty, homes there are still more affordable than in Hong Kong.
A 2018 report by property site 99.co revealed that a buyer with S$2 million could afford a 1,000 sq ft flat at Cairnhill Circle, located near Orchard. But the same amount could only buy a 448 sq ft flat in Hong Kong's Kennedy Town.
Added Chandran: "There is also a strong sense of safety and security due to the tight rule of law, and there is more stability here."
Other factors such as the low crime rate and absence of natural disasters were a draw for George Chan, a Hongkonger who relocated to Singapore last year with his wife and their two-year-old son."
Just as we were once the birds in Oz (cheap cheap), now they are the new birds in SG..

is a vicious cycle lah
only thing is where are you currently in this whole pyramid, are you at the bottom layer, mid level or apex?

truth is every year there are people curse and swear of missing the boat, and hope next downturn can bring prices down, low enough so that they can enter the market with their affordability base on ownself income level 
 
however the harder truth is this, the boat ticket prices just keep getting higher each year, and the income gap keep widening, and if your income cannot match the tdsr limit, you simply can't afford to enter the market with the high barrier, unless got huge warchests full of hard cash to down-payment
 
plus the hdb resale price not going up fast enough to catch up the pte properties prices, need to top up even more cash if want to make the jump
 
another problem is older lh99 pte with lousy locations also weak in resale, hard for these owners to upgrade to better location or fh
 
thus more and more frustrations on the ground nowadays in the mass market, the ball game is now in the luxury segment. recently quite a lot of vibrance in high end segment 
 
we need fresh funds from overseas investors to come in and create euphoria to spice up market, especially in the mid high to high end market. hopefully the funds can spiral down to mid and mass market if the sellers choose to encash and downgrade for retirement

Diferent.
 
BTO after 5 years or 10 years, can only sell back to locals or long term PRs 
 
EC, after 5 years can sell to locals or any PR. After 10 years can even sell to foreigners.
 
The market size (hence market demand)  for EC expands  after 5 years and grow even larger after 10 years.

		Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/resale-unit-regency-park-reaps-165-mil-profit
Resale unit at Regency Park reaps $1.65 mil profit
 

The 1,959 sq ft unit on the second floor was bought for $1.6 million ($817 psf) in October 2006, and sold for $3.28 million ($1,674 psf) on July 15. The seller made a 105% profit, or an annualised profit of 6% over nearly 13 years.
 
The second top gain made over the week – a 59% profit of $1.65 million – was at Regency Park, located on Nathan Road in prime District 10. The 2,250 sq ft unit on the fourth floor was purchased for $2.78 million ($1,236 psf) in November 2006 and sold for $4.425 million ($1,967 psf) on July 12. 
 
At Dakota Residences, the seller of a penthouse unit made the third most profitable transaction of $1.58 million over the week. The 2,605 sq ft, four-bedroom unit on the 19th floor was bought for $2.62 million ($1,005 psf) in July 2008 when it was newly launched, and sold for $4.2 million ($1,612 psf) on July 12. The seller made a 60% profit, or an annualised profit of 4% over 11 years.
 
 
On the other hand, the greatest loss incurred over the week was from the resale of a 2,390 sq ft unit at 8 Bassein, on Bassein Road in prime District 11. The seller sold the property for $2.55 million ($1,067 psf) on July 12, and sustained a 13% loss of $388,000. The unit was purchased in May 2012 for $2.938 million ($1,229 psf). Over a holding period of seven years, this translates into an annualised loss of 2%.

Go to Acemundo's profileAcemundoMember's total reputation

		14,730 posts

Diferent.
 
BTO after 5 years or 10 years, can only sell back to locals or long term PRs 
 
EC, after 5 years can sell to locals or any PR. After 10 years can even sell to foreigners.
 
The market size (hence market demand)  for EC expands  after 5 years and grow even larger after 10 years.

 
 
by the way, just wondering, if the ec owner coupled divorce before 5th year or before 10th year, does that give them special concession to sell early?  do they have to sell to locals if they are selling early?

Go to therock's profiletherockMember's total reputation
 25,983
	
		7,828 posts
New tactics to avoid ABSD:
https://www.straitstimes.com/business/property/singapore-rich-kids-are-ending-up-with-penthouses-as-parents-skirt-taxes?cx_testId=20&cx_testVariant=cx_1&cx_artPos=2#cxrecs_s
 
Only works if they are old enough to buy...
 
 

 
Data is scant but property agents say they have seen a noticeable up-tick in apartments being bought by wealthy families for their children since the property cooling measures came into effect in July 2018. Additional buyer's stamp duty, or ABSD, is now levied at 12 per cent for second homes and 15 per cent for third and subsequent properties.
"Anecdotally we've observed more young home buyers entering the market," said Ms Christine Sun, the head of research and consultancy at OrangeTee & Tie. She said while first-time homebuyers who are not affected by ABSD dominate, many Singaporeans see the value of accumulating property as a store of wealth.	LUXURY SALESPrices are going in their favour, too. Data released last week from the Urban Redevelopment Authority showed private residential prices rose for the first time since the housing curbs were introduced. Dwelling values jumped 1.5 per cent in the three months through June 30, spurred by luxury apartment sales.
It's often the parents taking the lead on the house hunting.
 
 
"The high ABSD rate has induced parents to act vicariously, using their children's names to acquire another private residential property," said Mr Alan Cheong, the executive director of research and consultancy at Savills (Singapore). "(Parents are) either genuinely concerned that their children won't have the wherewithal to acquire private residential properties on their own, or using the first reason as an excuse to acquire properties for themselves."

Not exactly. I am disagreeing with the spirit of your statement that hdb owner gets poorer while the rich private property gets richer. While it is not directly mentioned, it suggests a link that the rich property owner profit from their appreciating private property while the hdb property owner gets poorer.  
I don't believe they can get poor because the appreciation of their property is slower. The private property owner also do not necessary get rich from property because rental income is paltry and realisation of capital gains also takes a long time. 
 
I believe these people got rich or poor largely through their main source of income and only partially from property income. Even if we pick examples of owners of multi private properties, they probably can get rich through rental collection of multi private properties because they have earned enough from their main source of income to afford so many. 
 
It is true that going forward, private property have higher likelihood to fare better but still there is still no direct link of poorness to owning a hdb.

 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
Foreigners are coming to town.
 
Expensive SG ... still think property prices gonna drop? 
 
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/nouvel-18-sells-16-units-90-buyers-are-foreigners
Nouvel 18 sells 16 units; 90% of the buyers are foreigners
 

On the weekend of July 20 and 21, City Developments Ltd (CDL) released 30 units at luxury, freehold project, Nouvel 18. To date, 16 units or more than half of the units released have been sold, according to CDL. Units sold were predominantly three- and four-bedroom apartments.
 
About 90% of the buyers are said to be foreigners. “The foreign buyers were predominantly from Hong Kong and China,” 
 
Selling prices start from $4.016 million for a two-bedroom-plus-study; $4.88 million for a three-bedroom unit; $5.28 million for a three-bedroom-plus-study; and from $7.63 million for a four-bedroom-plus-study.
 
According to CDL, the average selling price of Nouvel 18 is $3,300 psf. This reflects a 20% premium to the valuation price of $2,750 psf in the PPS.

The other is due to last enbloc fever of FH projects, FH land is a thing of the past, all GLS is 99, if no enbloc where to find FH?
HDB/PTE different ball game, for PTE can enbloc top up lease to fresh 99. FH LH both got pro and con. Example FH not be in as good location as LH,next to mrt etc.

If concern of lease run down,can adopt appropriate approach at different stages of the 99 years.Example, sell within first 10-20 years.
 
Without enbloc, all future new launches to be only LH. For me, I won't be too duly concerned about it. High sell psf for new launches, I see more 'value' in resale, and those new 99 will eventually be older resale too. So even for old 20-30 years LH resales, may represent a 'value' buy whether own stay or rental capital appreciation investment.
Example, buying old resale own stay just put in 50-100k reno to 'brand new'. Buying for rental, lower cost pay less interest to bank higher yield etc.
 
Again, 99 years is a very long time can cover 2 generations. For the buyer, probably won't even have the chance to see lease running down to zero.
'Go resale for better value'

Chances of a September Fed rate cut increase
 
-The fed funds futures market now points to a 74% chance of at least a quarter-point rate cut at the Fed’s September meeting, according to CME FedWatch tool.
 
-Traders are also pricing in two more cuts to the benchmark lending rate to a range of 150 to 175 basis points by the end of 2019.
 
-The Fed on Wednesday dropped the target range for its overnight lending rate to 2% to 2.25%, or 25 basis points from the previous level.
 
-The central bank also left the door open to future cuts, saying it will “act as appropriate to sustain the expansion” as it continues to evaluate the incoming data.

don't understand... why does understanding tdsr and msr difference cause hdb price to plunge? 
 
I understand the 2017 enlightenment that hdb value become zero at 99th year caused hdb price to plunge,but why tdsr and msr have this effect

I dunno.....my young staff explained to me.  That’s why he said he does not want to buy new HDB flat.  He wants to buy EC which will become privatised eventually.  His argument is that as long as your future buyer is capped from borrowing more (vis-a-vis private property), it will be difficult for one to see good appreciation even if your resale HDB property is in downtown CBD. He further reasoned to me another cap is foreigners are never allowed to buy HDB.  As long as there is a barrier to market demand, the good cannot achieve its maximum price appreciation.  Sounds broadly logical to me.
 
Then i asked him why don’t jump straight to a resale condo with the same quantum?  He said they are old, must reno, no modern facilities and most of all, sometimes banks can’t match the resale owners high asking px makes him choose EC over resale.  
 
Well...if this is how the buyers are thinking....and if more think this way....tell me how will the price of HDB be like in the future.  Ok, maybe not plunge....but you get the drift.

		Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts

HDB was never meant to be an asset until Mr Mah talked it up..
Now despite Mr Lawrence Wong's comments, people still expect to make millions and many still expect the government to rescue them when the lease is up.. and this is despite the numerous posts and comments on the lease issue..
Some HDBs are really impressive, in design and some have wonderful views... but ultimately they are an affordable way for people to live comfortably and safely. That's their main goal.
I categorically disagree about asset definition. 
Anything that can be used to house oneself and family for decades has inherent value and can be seen as assets.
 
One can still cash out after 20 years to downgrade size and partially fund retirement.
 
It retains a good portion of its value over time and suffers minimal annual depreciation, unless you buy one with 30 years lease left.
 
Recently heard of many young people (mostly very savvy although) buying old resales, at cut throat low prices. The grants can be humongous.

These two are amongst the largest sites available in SG.
 
Regardless of lease they are extremely hard for developers to swallow due to extremely high quantum.
Ageing population does not mean more people buy FH.
 
It means more will go for short leases. Even 60 year private LH should be in the pipeline already.
 
Not everyone subscribes to full investment and inheritance through housing (FH). For some, partial investment and inheritance (private LH) will suffice. For some, they do not even consider it (HDB).

 
read again, i did not say more aging population mean more people buy fh
i am saying aging property is like aging population, there is a growing number in the pipeline as the years go by
 
do not mix up aging population with fh demand
fh demand is not dependent on the no of aged, its dependent on the affordability of the buyers
also the price is dependent on the supply, if it is scarce compared to lh99, fh prices will have an advantage over lh99
plus fh do not depreciate to zero value, hence is superior in retaining value compared to lh99
 
people who invest in fh do not mind the additional quantum over lh99, because end of the day if enbloc, the payout will more than compensate the quantum
 
the question is, all else being equal, which has a bigger enbloc demand and which command a premium - fh or lh99?
ask any developer, the answer is clear
 

this is exactly why people nowadays go for fh instead of old lh99

the most worrying thing about holding to a old lh99 is not just the fact that it depreciate to nothing at 99th year, but also more and more aged lh99 coming up in the next decade
 
what is going to happen to the prices of these 50yr old hdb and lh99 condos?

As mentioned prior, no one size fits all, diff folks diff requirements.
Today, whether buying for own stay/rental yield/capital appreciation, I would pick a old resale LH over new launch 99lh.
 
-New units new lease 99, but then you are also paying for it at high psf.
-Old units less lease years, you also pay less psf/overall quantum.
 
'Go resale for better value'
 
An example of buyer paying $2.05 million for a unit with 62 years lease balance, when could have gotten a brand new 99LH or FH of smaller size. 
Could be enbloc millionaire as replacement home for the space, investor punting for future enbloc ... or both 
 
https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/resale-unit-nexus-reaps-122-mil-profit
 

At Bedok Court, the seller of an eighth floor unit made the third most profitable transaction of the week with a $1.11 million gain. The 2,411 sq ft, three-bedroom unit was bought for $940,000 ($390 psf) in November 1996, and sold for $2.05 million ($850 psf) on July 18. The seller made a 118% profit, or an annualised profit of 3% over nearly 23 years.
 
Located in District 16, at Bedok South Avenue 3, the 99-year leasehold Bedok Court was developed by Bedokville Development, a subsidiary of Lum Chang Holdings. Completed in 1985, it has 62 years left on its lease.

pls lah, let your son independently decide for himself when the time come lah
 
you mean nowadays parents need to decide even this kind of thing for the children ah? so dependent on the parent meh

 
On the contrary, don't you think I am actually giving him more choices?  He can choose to dispose of the private property and buy a resale HDB.  On current regulations, he can buy a HDB on the resale market immediately.  
 
So yes, as parents, I will do all I can to allow my children have more choices in life.  You mean, given a choice, you will rather let him go through hardships (and yeah, maybe learn from the hard knocks and emerge stronger lol) then to give him as much options as possible to decide what to do?  
 
Well, I'm fine if that's how you wanna raise your child or children.  For me, I honestly feel there is no need to ask my child to `fight' for the subsidy and grants when it was meant to help others who actually need it.  While technically, as a citizen, he is entitled to this first bite of the cherry, I feel there is no need to encourage such `entitlement' mentality, give it to others who need it more than him.  
 
Having said the above, and as mentioned in the previous post of mine, I actually feel he will be better off to start off with a private property and build his wealth from there than start with HDB.  Incidentally, I subscribe to the belief HDB is not an investment tool.  We really should keep it as the basic form of roof / shelter for the majority of the population.  The moment we relax that assumption, I'm positive we WILL end up like Hong Kong.

I categorically disagree about asset definition.
 
Anything that can be used to house oneself and family for decades has inherent value and can be seen as assets.
 
One can still cash out after 20 years to downgrade size and partially fund retirement.
 
It retains a good portion of its value over time and suffers minimal annual depreciation, unless you buy one with 30 years lease left.
 
Recently heard of many young people (mostly very savvy although) buying old resales, at cut throat low prices. The grants can be humongous.

 
what you mentioned above is totally contradictory to this newspaper article published today (see underlined below): 
https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/big-read-no-easy-answers-hdb-lease-decay-issue-public-expectations-have-change-first
 
 
 
"To these long-time homeowners, it does not matter that in absolute terms, the price which they can get for their ageing flat will be many times higher than what they bought it for.
What weighs on their mind is the worry that they are not getting a high enough price, relative to what they could have gotten when the flat was younger or the cost of an alternative home on the market today.
 
Mr Ku Swee Yong, chief executive officer of International Property Advisor, noted that the situation has been made worse by buyers overpaying for ageing resale flats in recent years, and price decline going forward is “inevitable”.
“(The) prices of well-located old flats have reached high levels not commensurate with their future cash flow value (from a rental perspective),” he said."

Applying a common industry forecasting template that correlates the value of land with respect to its remaining lease, Mr Ku predicts that a flat which was completed in 1975 — and priced at S$860,000 today — would fetch only S$180,000 in 2054, when it has 20 years of lease left
In less than 30years all property in HK will be state owned! Hahah.

One thing going for FH property buyers is that although they may not see the capital come back in their lifetime, they can rest assured that their next generation will benefit some day.

People who buy such properties, in a lot of cases, are safekeeping it for future generations.
 
So I do hope you realise how much of a clash and how odd it sounds.

Go to sgcarmart2019's profilesgcarmart2019Member's total reputation
 119
	
		285 posts

Like I said you are indeed the best father ever a child can find lol. Giving them the `best environment' for them to learn how to grow up and be successful in life.  
 
And you must be very rich....is your last name Ng?  Buying house is simple for you, hahaha...oh actually there is no need to buy....with a Ng surname, its inherited.....  
 
To me, having safety nets and more options are never a bad thing in life.  It allows one to boldly try different and more things without fear of making mistakes.  And making mistakes earlier in a person's life has less consequences than if the mistakes are made later in life.  This is why it gets harder for one to go into business when one is in his 40s or 50s since there are a lot to lose.  And in unforgiving Singapore, if there is no safety net, many of us know 1 mistake can be fatalistic and set one's life back for decades.  For every 1 successful romantic story of rages to riches, grinding it out through tough environment, there are 10,000 other failed business ventures.  
 
Without the net, most would play it safe and take the tried and tested path though we all know past success is not a guarantee of future performance. Again nothing wrong with this path and it is necessary for society to have such stability of 80/20 rule.  However, it is also usually when one is at wits end that they are either forced to try new things or they just give up.  Research may have shown that's when the mind is at its most creative but I rather not test this hypothesis.  Sgcarmart2019, You are welcome to try it on your children and I'm happy if your child turn out to be the next Steve Jobs.
 
So thanks, but no thanks.  I increase the chance of success for my children in this new world by encouraging them to try different things.  There is no need for them to follow the beaten path even if it means its proven to succeed or work.  There is also less templates to follow if one does different things from the masses so naturally they will be plenty of opportunities to learn to find solutions creatively on their own.  And certainly mistakes will be made and these mistakes made earlier in life will have less consequences and put them in good stead later in their career. 
 
Recently my son asked me if he should take triple science and Advanced Math for his Year 3 IP program.  So I asked him if he had thought what inspires him? (Note I did not ask which career path does he envision himself to take in the future....tempting, leading question but I deliberately took a different approach).  He came back a week later and told me actually he is inspired by his History teacher and he wants to teach History in the future. He wants to inspire young minds like his teacher did to him and his class and he also enjoys imparting knowledge and coaching his juniors.
 
He also know this is probably not what my wife would like to hear because she is a doctor.  However, I told him, follow your dreams not what you think we want you to be.  Furthermore, being a doctor is a calling, you must want to serve in the health care sector to be a doctor.  Besides, one does not really have to take triple science at this stage to be a doctor anyway (that's my backdoor).  And I asked him to reflect further...does he enjoy inspiring minds (he must have watched those MOE ads in the cinemas) in general (my wife lectures in NUS Med School besides running her own clinic, haha) or because he enjoys history and at the same time has an engaging and inspiring History Teacher?  He is still thinking about it....well...sgcarmart2019....this is a snapshot of how I raise my children....
 
Sweet, bitter medicine....Poison?  I don't know....the script is still being written as I type.....haha
thank you for your compliment in the first sentence of this lengthy storyas I do not have time to read the rest of the LONG story, that's all I can say about your LONG story 
 
thank you for taking the effort and time though
I am sure you and your son will be live happily ever After

No prefect parents or perfect parenting. Reminds me of a sharing:
 
A child was crying and yelling in a play pen. 
 
When the mother was asked "why aren't you going to the child to carry him and calm him down?"
 
Mother's reply, "oh he will be fine in a awhile. Just leave him be and its good for his lungs to be exercising such"
 
Another mum "no way. I rather he be comforted and held to know he's loved and safe. He can exercise his lungs when he's older."
 
One's own child, one ought to know better. Hopefully this is  still true and holds water when its time to be stretched them lung muscles.

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts

I quote what you written in this forum earlier
 
"Ku Swee Yong has made so many erroneous predictions and assumptions that I have lost count.
 
You would do better in the property market following my posts from 2015.
 
He did not and would not analyse the whole market in complete contexts." 
 
these are your words right
 
beware he can sue you for publicly challenging his professionalism
In 2010, he wrote that buyers are not clear minded about buying shoeboxes and that there might not be real demand for such housing upon completion. Oddly, he used to live in a 120 sqft property overseas. If he can, what makes him feel that people cannot live in a place 3-4 times bigger? Buyers I felt were very clear about limitations of shoeboxes and went in with eyes wide open. All his reservations were quite unfounded. Shoebox apartments are still the first to sell out in new sales and continue to command the highest yielding premium across all private housing. Modern technologies have made living in smaller spaces so much more viable; I was surprised he did not see that.  
Nowadays the authorities are allowing even fewer of such units, and the price has kept turning northward, may not even get to buy any now as potential buyers missed their opportunity with increased taxes and CMs from that period.
 
In JAN 2018, after 4 years of index decline and market was in early stabilising and recovery state amidst worldwide raging prices in HK, China, etc, he claimed that it was too early to celebrate. Prices continued to run on month after month and was so hot that new CMs were installed in July 2018. In the same article, he also questioned how can 48,000 housing units explain for an increase of only 5,000 residents. The number crunching failed to include the ever increasing single person households and couples without children households. Much of the new supply was also to house older couples while more households are formed. Some of the units serve long term investment needs as well (buying for long term rent, inheritance etc). Some other figures in our population changes were not addressed.
 
In March 2018, he has made some good points about the ageing population and increase in flats available due to passing of all owners. But it was conflicting to read that prices of HDBs would continue to fall while there would be no demand from the young. It was odd also to suggest countermeasures to absorb the supply, such as allowing children to inherit the flat even if they do not meet eligibility conditions. Certainly, an easier policy for HDB would be simply to build less; ultimately, not everyone fancies an outskirt BTO flat. With new government grants in place, ultimately Govt would step in to provide the impetus for young couples to consider older HDBs, ready to absorb the supply if it comes.
 
These are just three of the major areas (based on his blog) in which I disagree with his views on housing. There are many more that I can find as well.
 
He should actually thank me for reading his articles and helping him raise his PR profiles.

Go to awhtc's profileawhtcMember's total reputation
 1,515
	
		872 posts

In 2010, he wrote that buyers are not clear minded about buying shoeboxes and that there might not be real demand for such housing upon completion. Oddly, he used to live in a 120 sqft property overseas. If he can, what makes him feel that people cannot live in a place 3-4 times bigger? Buyers I felt were very clear about limitations of shoeboxes and went in with eyes wide open. All his reservations were quite unfounded. Shoebox apartments are still the first to sell out in new sales and continue to command the highest yielding premium across all private housing. Modern technologies have made living in smaller spaces so much more viable; I was surprised he did not see that.
 
Nowadays the authorities are allowing even fewer of such units, and the price has kept turning northward, may not even get to buy any now as potential buyers missed their opportunity with increased taxes and CMs from that period.
 
In JAN 2018, after 4 years of index decline and market was in early stabilising and recovery state amidst worldwide raging prices in HK, China, etc, he claimed that it was too early to celebrate. Prices continued to run on month after month and was so hot that new CMs were installed in July 2018. In the same article, he also questioned how can 48,000 housing units explain for an increase of only 5,000 residents. The number crunching failed to include the ever increasing single person households and couples without children households. Much of the new supply was also to house older couples while more households are formed. Some of the units serve long term investment needs as well (buying for long term rent, inheritance etc). Some other figures in our population changes were not addressed.
 
In March 2018, he has made some good points about the ageing population and increase in flats available due to passing of all owners. But it was conflicting to read that prices of HDBs would continue to fall while there would be no demand from the young. It was odd also to suggest countermeasures to absorb the supply, such as allowing children to inherit the flat even if they do not meet eligibility conditions. Certainly, an easier policy for HDB would be simply to build less; ultimately, not everyone fancies an outskirt BTO flat. With new government grants in place, ultimately Govt would step in to provide the impetus for young couples to consider older HDBs, ready to absorb the supply if it comes.
 
These are just three of the major areas (based on his blog) in which I disagree with his views on housing. There are many more that I can find as well.
 
He should actually thank me for reading his articles and helping him raise his PR profiles.

 
DrWealth
 
https://www.drwealth.com/interview-with-ku-swee-yong/
Go to awhtc's profileawhtcMember's total reputation
 1,515
	
		872 posts
My take is Singapore is flushed with a supply of expensive 99-year LH properties from 2019 to 2021.  These prices were the result of very confident developers and cash-rich enbloc owners.  The rental is not able to support these prices, hence together with ABSD most investors should be out.
 
If there are still many owner-buyers, then Singapore is likely to have an escalating number of households with very large debts/loans above $1 mil.  If this economy downturn continues to next year, there is a good chance that many of these new buyers will be struggling with their loans.
 
A BTO is perfectly fine with its high government subsidy and low cost of ownership.  I think the 99-year lease issue of HDB is overblown.  If HDB relaxes its ownership rule (eventually I think it will with some restrictions), even with 20 or 30 years left, the rental yield is very attractive and able to support prices.

DrWealth
 
https://www.drwealth.com/interview-with-ku-swee-yong/
1. Initially, Singaporeans didn’t need to pay ABSD for second property. 
Then 5%, then 7%, then 12%.
 
2. BSD from 3% increased to 4%.
 
3. Carpark lot provision fell from 100% to 50-80%.
 
From a practical perspective, how much should property prices fall to compensate for these additional upfront costs and decline in material offering?
 
4. Land costs and construction costs has and will continue to escalate. 
 
Even for a charity developer who will charge 0 profits or even take a small loss, how low can it go???
 
How come these are not taken into consideration at all? Deliberately ignored, or just blind spot?

Go to therock's profiletherockMember's total reputation
 25,983
	
		7,828 posts
I'm not sure if this is a good thing...
Seniors using their CPF to finance a home instead of saving the $$ for daily use after retirement..
https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/housing/older-hdb-flats-back-in-demand-after-cpf-rule-change
 

 
SINGAPORE - The demand for ageing Housing Board flats is on the rise, two months after the authorities changed Central Provident Fund (CPF) rules to expand the pool of people who can buy them.
Some 564 flats aged more than 40 years changed hands in May and June, up from 403 in the same period last year.
Transactions for flats between 30 and 40 years old rose 10.4 per cent to 1,219 units over the same period.
This means that older flats - those over 30 years old - made up 44.9 per cent of the total resale transactions in those two months, up from 40.6 per cent in 2018.
Ms Christine Sun, head of research at real estate agency OrangeTee & Tie, which compiled the data in its half-yearly report, said on Tuesday (Aug 6) that the second quarter usually sees more sales.
But the fact that resale transactions have also increased - by 5.6 per cent year on year - shows that "apart from a seasonal effect, the recent CPF changes may have been a major catalyst that has spurred buying demand last quarter".
 
 
Since May, buyers have been allowed to use more of their CPF monies and get bigger HDB loans for ageing flats, as long as the property's remaining lease covers the youngest buyers until the age of 95.

Go to awhtc's profileawhtcMember's total reputation
 1,515
	
		872 posts
VERS is just government taking back the HDB earlier and compensate the market rate, which can be already very depressed with about 10-30 years lease left.
 
To me, it is more of a mechanism for HDB to space out the redevelopment of more valuable plots of land in an orderly manner rather than to really benefit the owners.
 
The background is HDB built a lot of HDBs in the 1970s-1980s, therefore resources will be strained if these HDBs lease start to go to 0 within a time-span of 10-20 years.
  Vers allows for more orderly redevelopment 
https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/housing/vers-allows-for-more-orderly-redevelopment

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
The Govt already explained that VERS is based on a resettlement scheme rather than profit based scheme.
 
It's like LUP or HIP programme, every flat will be in queue to receive this. The VERS payout will also be less generous than SERS because the flats that qualify for SERS in terms of density and size of sites, would be exhausted by then (20 years time). 
 
There is a need to space VERS carefully so that it will be sequential. It is also based on vote. From my sensing, very well located flats may reject VERS as the overall potential rental income may be higher than the payout Govt is willing to give, but largely also depends on where the Govt re-settles them. OCR are most likely to benefit, as rental does not appear as lucrative as voting for VERS and getting a new flat (anywhere might be equal or better than their current location).

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
Supposing they bought high for a 5rm flat, 39 years old at 800,000, 
 
Let's say they get to enjoy the prime location for another 30 years. I think the compensation at VERS should be say 300,000 to 500,000 (factoring in land inflation plus marginal value of old building with 30 years lease left). 300K to 500K may be enough for downgrade then (30 years later) in terms of size or location but unlikely to buy a new 5rm flat at the same locality.
 
I predict (blind prediction and guess) a new BTO 3rm flat in the same locality will be about 500K then, with 2rm at about 300K. This arrangement makes it easy for Govt to finance the resettlement. Their 5rm flat (space) is switched to 2 X 3rm or 2rm flat. One is sold back to owner (fresh lease or 30 - 99 years), the other is sold to a new buyer to finance the construction of new HDB blocks.
 
It's win-win or at worst, nobody loses. Bao Jiak or bueh pai jiak.
 
Remember that the survival of the future Govt depends on whether they get this right. Therefore, they will.

Supposing they bought high for a 5rm flat, 39 years old at 800,000, 
 
Let's say they get to enjoy the prime location for another 30 years. I think the compensation at VERS should be say 300,000 to 500,000 (factoring in land inflation plus marginal value of old building with 30 years lease left). 300K to 500K may be enough for downgrade then (30 years later) in terms of size or location but unlikely to buy a new 5rm flat at the same locality.
 
I predict (blind prediction and guess) a new BTO 3rm flat in the same locality will be about 500K then, with 2rm at about 300K. This arrangement makes it easy for Govt to finance the resettlement. Their 5rm flat (space) is switched to 2 X 3rm or 2rm flat. One is sold back to owner (fresh lease or 30 - 99 years), the other is sold to a new buyer to finance the construction of new HDB blocks.
 
It's win-win or at worst, nobody loses. Bao Jiak or bueh pai jiak.
 
Remember that the survival of the future Govt depends on whether they get this right. Therefore, they will.

Go to Invigorated's profileInvigoratedMember's total reputation
 4,616
	
		1,101 posts
One method to lessen the impact is to compensate at market value of new flat.
 
Says one buys a new 5 room flat now at bto price of 400k. (2019)
 
In 50 years time, say if it's 1.08 mil for a new 5 room bto in the same area then (e.g. 2% pa compounded), the govt may compensate 50% of that value at 540k under Vers, meaning a slower appreciation of only 0.6% p.a. for the initial 400k but at least it doesn't run to 0. 
 
This may be similar to what is currently done under lease buyback, which isn't very popular as market value falls. The one I'm proposing here is tagged to new HDB flat instead, not the market value of an old flat as what's currently done.
 
The elderly owners may choose to downsize and buy a 2 bedroom with some balance cash left, as they probably need lesser room and at the same time, the government can take back the units and provide for new couples who need more space.

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://www.99.co/blog/singapore/sale-of-older-hdb-flats-up-40-from-last-year/
Sale of Older HDB Flats Up 40% From Last Year
 

More Older Flat Sold in Q2 2019
 
According to the Business Times, 564 flats that are aged 40 years or above were sold between May to June this year. This is 40 per cent higher than the same time last year (403 transactions). There was also a 10.4 per cent increase in transactions for resale flats between 30 to 40 years old, with 1,219 units changing hands.
 
To put things in context, this wasn’t just an isolated rush for older flats. The volume of resale transactions also spiked almost 30 per cent between Q1 and Q2 of this year (6,726 transactions). The volume of older flats – 40 years or above – account for only about eight per cent of the transactions.

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://blog.moneysmart.sg/property/hdb-homeowners-resale-first-property/
My Resale Flat Journey: First Property is a 30-Year Old Resale Flat
 

About The Flat
 
Location Jurong West
Flat Price $335,000 (after $40,000 housing grants)
Year of Purchase 2018
Flat Type & Size 5-room flat/ 121 sqm
Remaining Length of Lease 69 years (as of May 2019)
Monthly Mortgage Amount & Loan Tenure About $1,600 18 years
Renovation Cost About $35,000
 
MS: We understand that your flat is about 30 years old. Was its age a concern for you?
 
One reason why I bought a resale flat is that it is more spacious for my family. This flat is about 120 sqm and the kids have more space to run around. Sometimes my parents or my wife’s parents will visit. So it’s better to have more space.
 
We still have 69 years left on the lease which is good enough for us. Our children and future generations are likely to buy their own homes anyway, so we don’t need to worry about leaving this flat for them. As we are planning to use this flat as a home, I think it’s good enough. For the next generation, you don’t need to bother as the kids will buy their own homes.
 
Although this is an old estate, the area is well taken care of by the Town Council and HDB alao carries out upgrading of the flats.
 
 
MS: Do you see your flat as an investment?
 
When we were weighing the pros and cons of buying a 30-year-old flat compared to a newer one, we did think about this issue. However, we feel that a house is for the long-term and one that would see us through our old age. Instead of hoping to make a profit from moving houses, we would rather stay in one flat and finish paying our housing loan sooner, so that we can free up our finances for other things.
 


Edited August 7 by Mercs

Go to Icedbs's profileIcedbsMember's total reputation
 16,579
	
		6,254 posts

MS: Do you see your flat as an investment?
 
When we were weighing the pros and cons of buying a 30-year-old flat compared to a newer one, we did think about this issue. However, we feel that a house is for the long-term and one that would see us through our old age. Instead of hoping to make a profit from moving houses, we would rather stay in one flat and finish paying our housing loan sooner, so that we can free up our finances for other things.
 

 
I know a lot of people have the same mentality as above. When they are in their  early 30s, they look at their current finances and think that if they want to enjoy a spacious flat, then they have to go for an old flat because that's what their affordability level is.
 
Problem is when pple reach their 40s, they would have grown their income and savings.  And human has tendency for greed in wealth. When they grow wealthier, they want even more money, and  it become painful when their biggest investment is either not making money or may even be depreciating.  They will not be thinking the same like when they were in their 30s.  To add fuel to fire, their friends in their 40s, may have already make some good profit in their property investment, but it is not working out for them. 
 
In my daily business, it become very clear to me that property investment, like anything else in life, is either you "suffer" first in the beginning and enjoy later in the future years or you take a comfortable path in the beginning and then you "suffer" later in the future years. There is simply no escape from this....whether it is career, marriage, education, investments, etc.....it is the same. 

Edited August 7 by Icedbs

Problem is when pple reach their 40s, they would have grown their income and savings.  And human has tendency for greed in wealth. When they grow wealthier, they want even more money, and  it become painful when their biggest investment is either not making money or may even be depreciating.  They will not be thinking the same like when they were in their 30s.  To add fuel to fire, their friends in their 40s, may have already make some good profit in their property investment, but it is not working out for them. 
 
In my daily business, it become very clear to me that property investment, like anything else in life, is either you "suffer" first in the beginning and enjoy later in the future years or you take a comfortable path in the beginning and then you "suffer" later in the future years. There is simply no escape from this....whether it is career, marriage, education, investments, etc.....it is the same. 

 
if i were a property agent, i would advise my clients to keep their home and property investments separate instead of "suffering".  a person should never be pressured into making investments as possibility of making mistake is high under such circumstance.
 
a fully paid up and comfortable albeit budget home for the family to build their lives gives one a peace of mind to undertake higher risk investments to build weath be it property, stocks, forex etc at his own pace.
 
the stability will also provide kids a good environment to develop and pursue their own dreams.
 
the upgrade game has gotten many families into trouble than necessary because not all will succeed given the risky nature
 
 

Edited August 8 by Enye

this report say old hdb about 40yr age which is left 60yr tenure average transactions price at 330k 
 
compare this to a brand new 5room bto which is price about 350k to 400k+ in ocr, would you want to save a meagre 50k to buy a resale 40yr old hdb?
 
if you compare to a resale of new unit just 5yr old, ie left 94yr. the resale is average 150k more than bto price
 
using the same example if a 5yr old 5room bought at ulu location at 350k from hdb in 2014 then resale at 500k today , from 94yr to 60yr is difference equal 500k - 330k =170k, ie 34yr difference is worth 170k, so per mth is $420, similar to the 69yr jurong west resale hdb example posted earlier
 
however this depreciation is true only for old hdb up to 40yr age
 
tiagong the older a lh99 gets, say above 60yr or 70yr, the depreciation may shoot up at a much sharper rate, but currently no past data to support such speculation

Go to Icedbs's profileIcedbsMember's total reputation
 16,579
	
		6,254 posts

if i were a property agent, i would advise my clients to keep their home and property investments separate instead of "suffering".  a person should never be pressured into making investments as possibility of making mistake is high under such circumstance.
 
 

 
Unfortunately, a lot of pple are not savvy in investment instruments. They know a bit about stocks, unit trust, REITs etc...but they don't have time to manage the portfolio themselves. As a result, most buy into unit trust or ILP where over time, the management fees erode their returns . Or they dwell into stocks, didn't monitor and then ended up with half of what they begin with. In the end, most average consumers conclude that either the fund managers are sneaky or other investments are simply too risky for them.
 
Hence the only viable investment most average pple have is their home. So my take is that if the home is your only possible investment, then please make it a sound one especially when one is still young. Like all investments, younger age is a big advantage because of the long investment horizon for compounding returns.  Work hard, take a bit more risk and don't settle for comfort when one is still young (early 30s). There is plenty of time for comfort and low risk investments when one is old.
 
This is not to say all young pple must stretch their budget for their home, but they can make sacrifices for sound property  investment principle. For example sacrifice space for better location. Or sacrifice space for a newer home where the chances of capital appreciation is higher. Property is the biggest investment for most pple, so whether they look at it as a roof over their head, or just a home to sleep at night, it is still their biggest spending so make it a sound one where it can grow over time.

Edited August 8 by Icedbs

		6,462 posts
The owner really huat big time, almost 100% appreciation in ~10 years!!
 
Boon Keng 5-room HDB flat sells for record $1.2 million in July, but resale prices dip 0.2%
 

 
SINGAPORE - Despite a Boon Keng five-roomer selling for a record sum, HDB resale prices remained pretty much stable last month, new figures show.
 
The 39th-floor unit at City View@ Boon Keng went for $1,205,000 - $5,000 more than the previous record for a HDB resale set by a five-room flat in Boon Tiong Road, in Tiong Bahru, in April.
 
It was the second time this year that a City View unit has claimed the record after another five-room unit in the adjacent Block 9 sold for $1,185,000 in January.
 

The 714-unit development was completed in 2011, and five of the nine flats there sold this year have gone for over a million dollars.
 
Analysts say it has proved popular because it is a new development located among ageing counterparts in a mature estate and in close proximity to two MRT stations - Bendemeer on the Downtown Line and Boon Keng on the North-East Line.
 
Despite that record price, HDB resale prices in July decreased by 0.2 per cent from June, although the number of resale transactions went up by 11.9 per cent, according to data released by SRX Property on Thursday (Aug 8).
 
The prices of three-room and five-room flats fell by 0.9 and 0.1 per cent respectively.
 
Four-room prices remained flat while prices for executive flats saw an increase of 0.3 per cent.
 
Non-mature estate prices increased by 0.2 per cent while mature estate flats were 0.8 per cent lower.
 

"What we are seeing in mature estates on one end is the value of older flats beginning to dip as the flats age, and on the other newer flats like those at City View starting to enter the resale market at higher prices," said property agent OrangeTee & Tie's head of research and consultancy Christine Sun.
 
The highest transaction price for a non-mature estate resale flat last month was for an executive flat in Hougang which sold for $908,000. Overall, resale prices were 0.8 per cent lower than in July last year.
 
There were 2,120 resale transactions last month, up from 1,895 in June. This was 17 per cent lower than in July last year, but 19.7 per cent higher than the average volume in July for the last five years.
 
The increased sales volume can be attributed to a number of factors, said Ms Sun.
 
"Sales activities usually pick up after the June holidays," she added.
 
"Demand for resale flats, especially older units, may have increased after the recent CPF rule changes that allow buyers to use more of their CPF savings as well as get bigger HDB loans for older flats.
 
"But prices may remain weak due to the increasing supply of flats that have reached MOP (minimum occupation period), with more sellers vying for buyers."
 
SRX estimated in its report that 680 flats could enter the resale market within the next three months as these units approach their five-year MOP.
 
The overall median transaction over X-value (TOX) was negative $1,000 last month, a decrease of $1,000 from the previous month.
 
The median TOX measures whether people are overpaying (positive TOX) or underpaying (negative TOX) relative to the SRX Property X-value estimated market value for flats.
 
Only three-room flats had a positive median TOX of $2,000 last month. Four-room, five-room and executive flats saw a median TOX of negative $1,000, negative $1,000 and negative $7,000 respectively.
 
Kallang Whampoa saw the highest median TOX of $18,000.

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts

I know a lot of people have the same mentality as above. When they are in their  early 30s, they look at their current finances and think that if they want to enjoy a spacious flat, then they have to go for an old flat because that's what their affordability level is.
 
Problem is when pple reach their 40s, they would have grown their income and savings.  And human has tendency for greed in wealth. When they grow wealthier, they want even more money, and  it become painful when their biggest investment is either not making money or may even be depreciating.  They will not be thinking the same like when they were in their 30s.  To add fuel to fire, their friends in their 40s, may have already make some good profit in their property investment, but it is not working out for them. 
 
In my daily business, it become very clear to me that property investment, like anything else in life, is either you "suffer" first in the beginning and enjoy later in the future years or you take a comfortable path in the beginning and then you "suffer" later in the future years. There is simply no escape from this....whether it is career, marriage, education, investments, etc.....it is the same.
I do not subscribe to the notion, must suffer first or later. As with most things, key is to know how to strike a balance. 
While human tendency to lust after $$$, should also learn to have some contentment and appreciate what already have.
 
If wanna compare, then never ending story. From HDB to Condo to Landed to GCB. One mountain highet than the other, can never reach the peak.
 
As mentioned prior, HDB is meant for own stay roof over head, should not be taken solely as investment tool.
 
Those that went the BTO route, when saved enough for DP, then go for investment property and let time do its thing. 
Most likely the property will pay for itself via rental and also capital appreciation in due course.
 
As with any investment to create wealth, should not let it compromise lifestyle, YOLO. 
Other much more important stuff should take priority ... health happiness etc.

 119
	
		285 posts

I do not subscribe to the notion, must suffer first or later. As with most things, key is to know how to strike a balance.
 
While human tendency to lust after $$$, should also learn to have some contentment and appreciate what already have.
 
If wanna compare, then never ending story. From HDB to Condo to Landed to GCB. One mountain highet than the other, can never reach the peak.
 
As mentioned prior, HDB is meant for own stay roof over head, should not be taken solely as investment tool.
 
Those that went the BTO route, when saved enough for DP, then go for investment property and let time do its thing.
Most likely the property will pay for itself via rental and also capital appreciation in due course.
 
As with any investment to create wealth, should not let it compromise lifestyle, YOLO.
Other much more important stuff should take priority ... health happiness etc.

 
and its always good to stay vested in singapore properties yah
especially FREEHOLD !!

Go to Showster's profileShowsterMember's total reputation
 30,025
	
		5,886 posts
We generally suffer from confirmation bias.
 
People who continuously watch the public-private gap think it has to remain.
 
Those who only think of FH as the sole criteria of a property’s value will absorb only data that confirm their thinking.
 
Regarding whether youngsters feel if they should make money out of HDB, my suspicion is they either choose to not think about it, or they make corresponding pragmatic choices. When some of my young relatives sold their HDBs, they did so in an instant. Just 100k gain from the sale of BTO flat (barely over breakeven considering the renovations), they sold.
 
Look across history, and we can see a very dynamic picture of Singapore that is amenable to change in an instant. There are no fixed rules. More crucial is which direction things should go to benefit everybody at a social level.

I used to think nothing else but only FH until I started seriously looking around years ago. Now I am more open-minded to LH, perhaps the same open-mindedness to FH.

I agree with what you say.  Problem is, after seeing their parents generation making boatloads of money from their HDB, do you think it is easy for the current generation to accept that HDB is  just a roof over their head and it is perfectly fine if they don't make a cent out of it?  
 

https://www.99.co/blog/singapore/think-youll-be-rich-from-selling-your-hdb-heres-why-youre-wrong/Think You’ll Be Rich From Selling Your HDB? Here’s Why You’re Wrong.
 
"Sadly, this is not true. HDB flats are generally not good investment vehicles (compared to condos)"
 
 
 
Thanks for agreeing 
 
I feel it would be naive to think that the high gains of the past to be mirrored future. The property investment climate have changed, one mainly being CMs since 2009 putting a curb to the pace of rise in property prices, and ABSD which is not just a big hurdle during purchase, also eating into future profits.
 
That said, this is Expensive SG, property remain a sound investment option, just that now one need to have a longer term horizon.
 
And that is also why its 'good to be in as early as possible'  before prices get out of reach.
 
'SG property, always ideal to stay vested'

Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
Wanna know how much the agent comms for new launches? 
 
https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/real-estate/developers-dangle-higher-commissions-to-clear-less-ideal-units
Developers dangle higher commissions to clear less ideal units
 
(They can go up to 3-4%; cash bonus may also be thrown in for ground floor or less-attractive facing units)
 

In today's market, agents expect developers to pay a minimum of 2.3 per cent commission for them to be motivated to clear any project.
 
"And for a boutique project, to get the visibility up, the commissions must be higher than 2.3 per cent."
 
Such higher commissions are more prevalent for higher-end projects, where there are relatively fewer buyers of such properties with large price quantums.
 
"Buying sentiment seems to have returned to the market, so it's a good time (for developers) to capitalise on this to lock in sales," 
 
SL Capital's Sky Everton is offering commissions of up to 3 per cent, while the Affinity at Serangoon - developed by a consortium led by Oxley Holdings - is said to be offering up to 3.7 per cent.
 
The commission for The Florence Residences by Logan Property is understood to be 1.8 per cent but there are additional cash incentives - which can range from S$5,000 to S$20,000 - for certain units.
 
However, there are also instances where developers are offering commissions under 2 per cent. This could be due to expectations of strong demand for the project.
 
Frasers Property's luxury development Rivière is understood to be offering a commission of 1.8 per cent, while the commission for City Development Limited and TID's EC Piermont Grand is said to be around 0.9 per cent.

		Go to Icedbs's profileIcedbsMember's total reputation
 16,579
	
		6,254 posts

But not easy to pass the RES exams leh.....
 
Heard only top 20% can pass
 
My friend got a degree from NUS also fail..... 
 
Wonder what it takes to pass? Anyone can share tips?

 
I am not sure what tips you need, but like all exams, you just need to study real hard for it. 
 
The syllabus itself is not tough, but I feel a lot of candidates are taking this while having some other jobs and totally underestimated the paper.  When I took this exam,  I prepared for it full time. 
 
Memory work will not be enough to pass this exam.  You can memorise the entire HDB & URA website and still fail in this paper  The exam test your application knowledge and it is hard when the candidate has not even been an agent yet! So your knowledge + logical deduction & reasoning has to be very strong. The section on answering 2 case studies would probably killed a lot of candidates.
 
The only advise I can give is practice the model exam questions like you have never done before in your entire education life. If you think you had enough of the practice, do another 50 questions more. Never underestimate this paper even if you are a lawyer or doctor.
 
This is probably one of the toughest industry certification exam to pass today.  If you are thinking of joining this line for the money, then look elsewhere. There are less agonising way to make money.  You need to be really passionate about serving home-owners where their pain is your pain and their investment success is your only measurement of achievement & fulfillment.  Otherwise, you will be happier with your corporate job.

Edited August 13 by Icedbs

Singapore Cuts Economic Forecast For This Year
 
The Singapore government slashed its full-year economic growth forecast to between zero growth and 1%, from its previous projection of between 1.5% and 2.5%, the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said on Tuesday (13 August).
Go to Mercs's profileMercsMember's total reputation
 181,360
	
		8,434 posts
https://sbr.com.sg/residential-property/news/private-condo-resales-322-882-units-in-july
Private condo resales up 32.2% to 882 units in July
 

Prices were down 0.5%.
 
Overall resale prices dipped 0.5% MoM but rose 0.1% YoY. Prices of resale condos located in the Rest of Central Region (RCR), Outside Central Region (OCR), and Core Central Region (CCR) fell across the board, registering declines of 1.1%, 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.
 
CCR and RCR recorded YoY price decreases of 2.4% and 0.9%, respectively, whilst OCR recorded a YoY price increase of 1.8%.
 
The highest transacted price for a resale unit in the month was achieved at Boulevard Vue, where a high-floor unit was transacted at $17.5m. In RCR, the highest transacted price was a unit at Dakota Residences resold at $4.2m. In OCR, the highest transacted price was a unit at Bayshore Park resold at $3.3m.

Stephen Riady Acquires Nassim Road GCB From OUE Unit For $95mil  
 

Using the comparable sale method, Cushman & Wakefield VHS valued the property – on the basis of market value – at $87 million, while Knight Frank valued it at $85.5 million using the direct comparison method.
 
Based on the property’s independent valuations, the average market value is about $86.25 million. As such, the $95 million consideration is 10.1 percent higher than the average market value.

https://www.edgeprop.sg/property-news/singhaiyi%E2%80%99s-parc-clematis-drew-more-5000-visitoron-preview-weekend
SingHaiyi’s Parc Clematis draws more than 5,000 visitors on preview weekend
 

SingHaiyi intends to release a first phase of 400 units. Units in the Contemporary Series, which range from one- to four-bedroom types, will have prices starting from $699,000. The Elegance Series has a mix of two- to five-bedroom units as well as penthouses with prices upward of $1.113 million. The Signature Series has a mix of three- to five-bedroom units, and prices from $2.056 million.
 
For the strata landed housing units, intermediate terraced houses start from $2.752 million while corner terraced houses are from $3.5 million. Detached houses start from $3.927 million.

I wrote on this a couple of year back.
 
We are just a tiny island that is at high risk of being submerged when global warming (melting of ice caps) plus tide / weather conditions combine. We have seen that a few times in several places in SG. The incidents will only increase in frequency. It doesn't affect any one location specifically but many / all locations in SG.
 
We need indeed to start working on this early. Our (small) size may play to our advantage though. Fortifying an island will be costly (100 billion as stated by PM), but it will be many (hundred or thousand) folds for larger countries.
 
If any country has the will and the resources to do it ultimately, it has to be Singapore.

The pics he showed were fairly alarming ... it seems that the Sentosa Cove, Downtown, up to Novena and whole East Coast area at risk of flooding so though steps are being taken the risk is there like raising the area. Will that affect one's decision to purchase properties in these areas cos these are where quite a few prime new developments are albeit 50-100 years risk?

Go to Icemaiden's profileIcemaidenMember's total reputation
 3,143
	
		368 posts
Agreed. I thought the idea of the poulders and dykes is quite smart and interesting. By using dykes out at sea to pump out the water, creating low lying dry land (lower than sea level but protected by the dykes), we will create new dry land along the eastern shoreline without having to buy loads of expensive sand - definitely more economical than reclaiming land. From a property investment perspective, in the mid to long term, those East Coast sea facing condos will be impacted. in the first place, these East Coast condos are already quite far away from the sea separated by the noisy ECP. Now the sea will move even further out. Just Tekong using this method is creating 2 Toa Payohs. Can't imagine how far out the poulders are going to be for the mainland. 
 
The good news is the majority of these "owners" of East Coast condos are foreigners - can't help every time I go Tg Rhu or Meyer or Mandarin Gardens or even Changi Business Park,  there are more Indian NRI people than locals.

Go to therock's profiletherockMember's total reputation
 25,983
	
		7,828 posts
https://www.gov.sg/microsites/ndr2019/greater-southern-waterfront
The idea of adding 9000 units to the Keppel area has many implications 
So will they be government HDB or EC
Or will they be private
 
If they are HDB then at one fell stroke the popularity of units in Punggol, Seng Kang and even the new paya lebar areas may become less popular. Given their connectivity issues in the northeast, the property value may plummet. 
Likewise those telok blangah flats will suffer with newer flats that have better views. 
 
If they are solely private then it’s also going to affect prices of older flats near HarbourFront and even newer ones like the Interlace
 
The draw to stay in town and pay high prices will be less. Those surrounding super expensive condos with less than 90 year lease will drop in price if the new ones are priced lower. 
 
The west coast highway may become busy. 
Henderson road will also become crowded. 
VivoCity stands to benefit big time and rental there may rise. 
 
Further down the road, in the quieter areas near train stations, units there stand to benefit from the GSW. 
But more ulu places like Whistler and Clematis may face competition and buyers will be drawn to these new ones in time and the upside for these units will be lower. 
 
Condos surrounding the Mapletree and the new PSA buildings will benefit greatly. 
Houses in the area will get more shops, recreational areas etc do its an exciting time for the belt from Pasir Panjang to Haw Par 
 
All in all, very exciting indeed..
More eateries, shops and parks sounds like all good news
Also if a recession comes buyers may hold fire and as the units surrounding the new Keppel area get older they will lose value and make it cheaper for buyers to get a unit. 
The government can build HDB units there at AMK prices and there will still be takers.

Another point for consideration is that each area will have its own distinctive ecosystem. 
 
GSW will be positioned as recreational, ultra premium and luxury seafront living. It’s highly possible for HDB lease here to be 30LH, 45LH or 60LH.
 
West is educational and manufacturing; east is recreational and cultural; North has its own industrial  and residential region.
 
Each sector may have its own distinctive pricing structure as well.

HDB flats on prime Keppel Club site: Premium prices or tweaked sales terms?

Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong in 2016, when he disclosed that the government could look at selling future public housing in the city under a different model - such as by imposing a longer MOP, a lease shorter than the existing 99 years, or a higher resale levy - to address the lottery effect.
